exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press (Flat)
exercises.description: A fundamental upper body compound exercise that involves pressing a barbell from chest level while lying on a flat bench.
instructions: Lie flat on the bench with feet planted firmly on the ground
Grip the barbell with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width apart, palms facing away
Lift the bar off the rack and position it directly above your chest with arms extended
Lower the bar to your chest in a controlled manner while keeping elbows at approximately 45 degrees
Press the bar back up explosively to the starting position, locking out at the top
tips: Retract your shoulder blades and keep them pinned to the bench throughout
Maintain a slight arch in your lower back with chest up
Keep your feet planted and drive through them for stability
common_mistakes: Flaring elbows out too wide (increases shoulder injury risk)
Bouncing the bar off the chest
Lifting hips off the bench during the press

exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press (Incline)
exercises.description: A bench press variation performed on an inclined bench that emphasizes the upper chest and front deltoids.
instructions: Set the bench to a 30-45 degree incline angle
Lie back on the bench with feet flat on the floor
Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width with palms facing away
Lower the barbell to your upper chest area with control
Press the barbell up and slightly overhead until arms are fully extended
tips: A 30-45 degree angle is optimal for upper chest activation
Keep elbows tucked at approximately 45 degrees to protect shoulders
Activate your glutes to maintain a solid foundation
common_mistakes: Setting the incline too steep (over 45 degrees shifts emphasis to shoulders)
Allowing the bar to drift too far forward

exercises.name: Barbell Bench Press (Decline)
exercises.description: A bench press variation performed on a declined bench that targets the lower portion of the chest.
instructions: Set the bench to a decline position with feet higher than head
Secure your feet under the foot pads for stability
Grip the barbell with hands wider than shoulder-width
Lower the bar to your lower chest area in a controlled motion
Press the weight back up to full arm extension
tips: Focus on keeping tension in the lower pecs throughout the movement
Maintain control as the decline position increases difficulty
Keep shoulder blades retracted
common_mistakes: Lowering the bar too high on the chest
Using momentum instead of controlled movement
Not securing feet properly leading to instability

exercises.name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Flat)
exercises.description: A chest-building exercise using dumbbells that allows for greater range of motion and works each side independently.
instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding a dumbbell in each hand at chest level
Position dumbbells with palms facing forward, elbows bent at 90 degrees
Press both dumbbells upward until arms are fully extended above chest
Lower the dumbbells with control until they're level with your chest
Press back up to the starting position
tips: Keep dumbbells at equal height throughout the movement
Maintain stable shoulder blade position against the bench
Allow for a greater stretch at the bottom than barbell press
common_mistakes: Allowing dumbbells to drift too far apart or together
Losing control at the bottom of the movement
Not maintaining equal tempo on both sides

exercises.name: Dumbbell Bench Press (Incline)
exercises.description: An incline dumbbell press that targets the upper chest with independent arm movement for balanced development.
instructions: Set bench to 30-45 degree incline and sit with back against the pad
Hold dumbbells at shoulder height with palms facing forward
Press dumbbells up and together in an arc motion until arms are extended
Lower dumbbells slowly to just below shoulder level
Maintain tension and press back to starting position
tips: Keep core engaged and feet planted firmly
Don't let dumbbells move further apart as you lower
Stop the dumbbells in line with each ear rather than bringing them together completely
common_mistakes: Setting incline too steep (reduces chest activation)
Lowering dumbbells too far causing shoulder strain

exercises.name: Dumbbell Chest Fly
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that stretches and contracts the chest muscles through a wide arc motion.
instructions: Lie on a flat bench holding dumbbells above chest with palms facing each other
Maintain a slight bend in elbows throughout the movement
Lower dumbbells out to sides in an arc motion until arms are parallel to ground
Squeeze chest to bring dumbbells back together above chest
Stop when dumbbells are in line with ears, not touching at the top
tips: Think about hugging a tree to maintain proper arc motion
Keep shoulder blades retracted against the bench
Use significantly lighter weight than pressing movements
common_mistakes: Lowering dumbbells below chest level (increases injury risk)
Bending elbows too much (turns into a press)
Bringing dumbbells all the way together at top (loses tension)

exercises.name: Cable Crossover
exercises.description: A cable exercise that provides constant tension on the chest muscles throughout the movement.
instructions: Set cable pulleys to appropriate height (high for lower chest, middle for middle chest, low for upper chest)
Grab handles with palms facing forward and step into the center
Lean slightly forward with one foot ahead for balance
Pull handles down and together in front of chest with slight elbow bend
Hold contraction briefly then return to starting position with control
tips: Imagine hugging a tree with your arms
Maintain stable torso position throughout
Focus on chest contraction rather than arm movement
common_mistakes: Using momentum or swinging the weight
Letting elbows bend too much during movement

exercises.name: Push-ups
exercises.description: A classic bodyweight exercise that builds chest, shoulder, and tricep strength.
instructions: Start in plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width
Keep body in a straight line from head to heels
Lower your body until chest nearly touches the ground
Keep elbows at 45-degree angle from body
Push back up to starting position maintaining rigid core
tips: Engage core and squeeze glutes to maintain straight body position
Don't let hips sag or pike up
Breathe in on the way down, out on the way up
common_mistakes: Letting hips sag creating lower back arch
Not lowering chest close enough to ground
Straining neck by looking forward instead of down

exercises.name: Machine Chest Press
exercises.description: A fixed-path pressing movement that targets the chest with built-in stability.
instructions: Adjust seat so handles are 2 inches below shoulders
Sit with back, glutes, and lower back firmly against the pad
Grip handles with feet planted firmly on the ground
Press handles forward while squeezing chest at the top
Return handles to starting position with control
tips: Keep shoulder blades squeezed against the back pad
Drive feet into floor for stability
Don't lock out elbows completely at the top
common_mistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Chest Dips
exercises.description: A bodyweight exercise that emphasizes the lower chest and triceps when performed with forward lean.
instructions: Grip dip bars and lift yourself to starting position with arms extended
Lean torso forward and bring chin to chest
Bend legs backwards and allow elbows to flare slightly outward
Lower body until upper arms are parallel to floor (90-degree angle)
Press back up to starting position without fully locking out elbows
tips: Greater forward lean increases chest activation
Use a wider grip for more chest emphasis
Keep slight hollow in lower back
common_mistakes: Staying too upright (shifts focus to triceps)
Fully locking out elbows at top

exercises.name: Barbell Row (Bent Over)
exercises.description: A fundamental back-building compound exercise that develops thickness in the lats and upper back.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding barbell with overhand grip
Hinge at hips with slight knee bend until torso is at 45-degree angle
Keep back straight and core braced throughout
Pull barbell to lower chest/upper abdomen by driving elbows back
Squeeze shoulder blades together at the top, then lower with control
tips: Focus on pulling with elbows, not hands
Keep the bar close to your body throughout the movement
Maintain neutral spine—don't round the back
common_mistakes: Standing too upright (reduces range of motion)
Using momentum instead of controlled pulling

exercises.name: Pendlay Row
exercises.description: An explosive barbell row variation where the bar returns to the floor between reps, emphasizing power and back strength.
instructions: Stand with barbell on floor and feet hip-width apart under the bar
Hinge at hips to 90 degrees with torso parallel to floor
Grip barbell with overhand grip slightly wider than shoulder-width
Explosively pull the bar to base of chest/lower ribcage
Lower bar back to floor completely before starting next rep
tips: Brace core hard and keep back flat throughout
Think about pulling the bar to your hips
Drive feet into floor as you pull
common_mistakes: Not returning bar fully to floor between reps
Allowing hips to rise during the pull
Elevating shoulders instead of pulling with lats

exercises.name: Dumbbell Row (Single Arm)
exercises.description: A unilateral rowing exercise that builds lat strength and size while allowing focus on each side independently.
instructions: Place right hand and right knee on flat bench with left leg stepped out to side
Keep back straight and parallel to ground
Grab dumbbell with left hand, arm fully extended
Row dumbbell up to side until upper arm is parallel with floor
Lower slowly back to starting position and repeat, then switch sides
tips: Pull the dumbbell toward your hip, not your chest
Keep torso stable—avoid rotating
Think about driving your elbow to the ceiling
common_mistakes: Pulling weight to chest instead of hip
Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Pull-ups
exercises.description: A bodyweight exercise using an overhand grip that primarily targets the back muscles with emphasis on lats.
instructions: Grip pull-up bar with hands wider than shoulder-width, palms facing away (pronated grip)
Hang with arms fully extended and engage core
Pull yourself up by driving elbows down toward hips
Continue until chin clears the bar
Lower yourself with control back to full arm extension
tips: Think about pulling your elbows down rather than pulling yourself up
Keep chest up and shoulder blades retracted
Avoid swinging or using momentum
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion at bottom or top
Kipping or swinging to generate momentum

exercises.name: Chin-ups
exercises.description: A vertical pulling exercise using an underhand grip that emphasizes biceps and lats with a narrower grip.
instructions: Grip bar with hands shoulder-width apart, palms facing toward you (supinated grip)
Hang with arms fully extended
Pull yourself up by contracting biceps and lats
Continue until chest reaches or clears the bar
Lower with control to starting position
tips: Narrower grip allows for more bicep and chest recruitment
Generally easier than pull-ups due to increased bicep involvement
Keep movement controlled without swinging
common_mistakes: Not lowering to full arm extension

exercises.name: Lat Pulldown (Wide Grip)
exercises.description: A cable machine exercise using a wide grip that isolates the latissimus dorsi muscles.
instructions: Sit on lat pulldown machine and adjust knee pad to secure thighs
Grip bar with overhand grip, hands wider than shoulder-width
Lean back slightly (about 30 degrees) with chest out
Pull bar down to upper chest by driving elbows down and back
Slowly return bar to starting position with arms fully extended
tips: Focus on pulling with your lats, not your arms
Keep chest up and maintain slight backward lean
Pull bar to upper chest, not behind neck
common_mistakes: Pulling bar behind neck (increases injury risk)
Not achieving full range of motion at top

exercises.name: Lat Pulldown (Close Grip)
exercises.description: A lat pulldown variation using a V-handle attachment that provides greater range of motion and targets mid-back.
instructions: Attach V-handle to lat pulldown machine and adjust knee pad
Grip V-handle with neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Sit with core engaged and slight backward lean
Pull handle down toward upper chest until it passes chin height
Slowly extend arms to return handle to starting position
tips: Pull elbows down toward hips rather than straight down
Don't pull the grip down too low (stops at upper chest)
Focus on squeezing lats at the bottom
common_mistakes: Pulling attachment down to waist (shifts work to shoulders and forearms)
Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Seated Cable Row
exercises.description: A horizontal pulling exercise that develops thickness in the middle back and lats.
instructions: Sit on cable row machine with feet on platform and knees slightly bent
Grip handle attachment with both hands and sit upright with neutral spine
Pull handle toward belly button while keeping torso stationary
Squeeze shoulder blades together at the end of the movement
Slowly extend arms to return to starting position
tips: Think about pulling your elbows toward your hips
Keep torso perpendicular to floor (beginners) or allow slight stretch forward (advanced)
Avoid excessive backward lean
common_mistakes: Using arms instead of back muscles to pull

exercises.name: Face Pulls
exercises.description: A cable exercise that targets the rear deltoids, upper back, and rotator cuff muscles.
instructions: Set cable to chest height and attach rope handle
Grip rope with neutral grip (palms facing each other)
Step back with shoulder-width or staggered stance
Pull rope toward face while separating the rope ends
Keep elbows high and pointed upward as you pull
tips: Focus on external rotation of shoulders at end of movement
Use higher reps (12-15) as this targets slow-twitch muscle fibers
Squeeze rear delts at peak contraction
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing form
Letting elbows drop below shoulder level
Not externally rotating at the shoulders

exercises.name: T-Bar Row
exercises.description: A compound rowing movement that builds back thickness and strength with a stable, angled bar position.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart straddling the bar
Hinge at hips with knees slightly bent and back neutral
Grip handles (wide for lats, narrow for mid-back)
Pull bar toward lower chest by driving elbows back
Squeeze shoulder blades together then lower with control
tips: Keep chest low and parallel to floor for full range of motion
Brace core throughout to protect lower back
Think about pulling elbows toward ceiling
common_mistakes: Standing too upright (reduces range of motion)
Using momentum instead of controlled pulls

exercises.name: Deadlift (Conventional)
exercises.description: A foundational compound lift that develops the entire posterior chain including back, glutes, and hamstrings.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over midfoot
Hinge at hips and grip bar just outside legs with hands
Lower hips, chest up, back flat, shoulders over or slightly in front of bar
Brace core, engage lats, and push floor away with feet to lift bar
Stand fully upright with hips and knees locked, then lower bar with control
tips: Think 'leg press the earth away' rather than pulling the bar
Keep bar close to body throughout—it should drag up shins
Maintain neutral spine—don't round back
common_mistakes: Rounding the back at any point in the lift
Starting with hips too low or too high
Not maintaining full-foot contact with ground
Letting bar drift away from body

exercises.name: Straight Arm Pulldown
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that targets the lats through a long range of motion with straight arms.
instructions: Attach rope or bar to high pulley on cable machine
Stand facing machine with feet shoulder-width apart and slight knee bend
Grip attachment with arms extended overhead, feeling lat stretch
Drive arms down in arc motion toward hips while keeping arms straight
Slowly return to starting position maintaining tension
tips: Bend hips back to 30-45 degree angle for proper positioning
Think about pulling with lats, not arms
Excellent for improving deadlift strength and lat engagement
common_mistakes: Not achieving full stretch at top position

exercises.name: Overhead Press (Barbell)
exercises.description: A fundamental shoulder-building exercise that develops all three deltoid heads and overhead strength.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, barbell at shoulder height
Grip bar just outside shoulders with palms facing forward
Brace core and squeeze glutes, maintaining slight upper back arch
Press bar overhead in straight line, moving head slightly back to clear bar
Lock out at top with bar over center of body, then lower with control
tips: Shrug shoulders at top to engage traps and protect rotator cuff
Keep elbows pointed forward and down under wrists
Don't arch lower back excessively—squeeze glutes to prevent this
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to sides
Pressing too far forward or behind body
Not reaching full elbow extension at top

exercises.name: Overhead Press (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: A shoulder press using dumbbells that allows for natural arm movement and independent work for each side.
instructions: Stand or sit with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing forward
Brace core and maintain neutral spine
Press dumbbells overhead until arms are fully extended
Keep dumbbells moving in straight vertical path
Lower dumbbells back to shoulder height with control
tips: Can be performed seated to reduce core involvement and isolate shoulders
Keep wrists neutral and locked in position
Avoid letting dumbbells drift too far forward or back
common_mistakes: Not pressing dumbbells in vertical line
Letting one side lag behind the other

exercises.name: Arnold Press
exercises.description: A shoulder press variation with rotation that targets all three deltoid heads with increased range of motion.
instructions: Sit or stand with dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing toward you
Press dumbbells up while simultaneously rotating wrists outward
Finish with arms extended overhead and palms facing forward
Reverse the movement by rotating palms back while lowering
Return to starting position with palms facing you at shoulder level
tips: The rotation targets rear delts in addition to front and side delts
Start with lighter weight than standard shoulder press
Move smoothly through the rotation
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing control of rotation
Not completing full range of motion at bottom

exercises.name: Lateral Raise (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that targets the side deltoids to build shoulder width.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, dumbbells at sides with palms facing body
Maintain slight bend in elbows throughout movement
Raise arms out to sides, leading with elbows
Lift until arms are parallel to ground (shoulder height)
Lower dumbbells with control back to starting position
tips: Lead with elbows, not hands—elbows should be higher than hands
Raise dumbbells 20 degrees in front of chest, not straight out to sides
Use lighter weight and focus on form over load
3-second count up, 3-second count down
common_mistakes: Leading with hands instead of elbows

exercises.name: Front Raise (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that primarily targets the front deltoids.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells in front of thighs, palms facing downward or toward body
Brace core and maintain neutral spine
Raise dumbbells forward in arc motion until arms are parallel to floor
Keep arms extended with slight elbow bend throughout
Lower dumbbells slowly back to starting position
tips: Can be performed alternating arms for each repetition
Keep torso stationary—don't lean back
Stop at shoulder height, no need to go higher
common_mistakes: Leaning back to assist the lift
Raising dumbbells too high above shoulder level

exercises.name: Rear Delt Fly (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: An isolation movement that targets the often-neglected rear deltoids.
instructions: Hinge forward at hips with slight knee bend until torso is nearly parallel to floor
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging down, palms facing each other
Raise dumbbells out to sides with slight elbow bend
Squeeze shoulder blades together at top of movement
Lower dumbbells with control back to starting position
tips: Keep back flat and core engaged throughout
Lead with elbows, not hands
Focus on rear delt contraction rather than weight used
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing form
Letting upper back do the work instead of rear delts

exercises.name: Upright Row (Barbell)
exercises.description: A pulling exercise that targets shoulders and traps by lifting the barbell vertically along the body.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding barbell at waist with overhand grip
Grip width slightly narrower than shoulder-width
Pull barbell up along body toward chin, leading with elbows
Keep elbows higher than wrists throughout movement
Lower barbell slowly back to starting position
tips: Wider grip works side deltoids more; narrower grip targets traps
Don't raise bar above upper chest/chin level
Engage shoulders and traps, avoid using lower back
common_mistakes: Using lower back to lift weight
Raising bar too high (increases shoulder impingement risk)
Swinging weight instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Cable Lateral Raise
exercises.description: A cable variation of lateral raises that provides constant tension throughout the movement.
instructions: Set cable pulley to lowest position and attach handle
Stand beside cable machine and grip handle with far hand
Maintain slight elbow bend and raise arm out to side
Lift until arm is parallel to ground at shoulder height
Lower with control back to starting position
tips: Cable provides constant tension unlike dumbbells
Can perform one arm at a time for better focus
Lead with elbow, not hand
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and losing form

exercises.name: Barbell Curl
exercises.description: A fundamental biceps exercise using a straight barbell to build arm size and strength.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, holding barbell with underhand grip
Start with arms fully extended, barbell at thigh level
Keep elbows tight to sides and curl bar up toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower bar with control to full arm extension
tips: Keep elbows stationary—don't let them move forward
Avoid swinging or using momentum
Full range of motion from complete extension to full contraction
common_mistakes: Swinging weight using back and hips
Not lowering to full arm extension
Using wrists instead of keeping them neutral

exercises.name: EZ Bar Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl using an EZ bar with angled grips that reduces wrist strain.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding EZ bar with underhand grip on angled sections
Arms fully extended with bar at thigh level
Keep elbows pinned to sides and curl bar toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at top, avoiding backward lean
Lower bar slowly to full extension before next rep
tips: Angled grip allows semi-supinated position that's easier on wrists
Wide grip emphasizes bicep width; narrow grip targets bicep peak
Maintain straight wrists—can slightly cock away from body for advanced lifters
common_mistakes: Using momentum instead of bicep strength
Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Dumbbell Curl
exercises.description: A biceps exercise using dumbbells that allows for natural arm movement and independent work.
instructions: Stand with dumbbells at sides, arms fully extended, palms facing forward
Keep elbows close to body throughout movement
Curl dumbbells toward shoulders, keeping upper arms stationary
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower dumbbells with control to starting position
tips: Can be performed alternating arms or simultaneously
Rotate pinkies toward ceiling as you curl for maximum contraction
Keep shoulders back and core engaged
common_mistakes: Letting elbows drift away from sides

exercises.name: Hammer Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl variation using neutral grip that targets the brachialis and brachioradialis.
instructions: Stand or sit with dumbbells at sides, palms facing each other (neutral grip)
Keep upper arms and elbows close to body
Curl dumbbells toward shoulders maintaining neutral grip throughout
Pause at top and squeeze biceps and forearms
Lower with control to starting position
tips: Neutral grip activates forearms and deeper bicep muscles (brachialis)
Targets upper and outer bicep for balanced arm development
Can perform seated to limit momentum
common_mistakes: Allowing elbows to move away from body

exercises.name: Preacher Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl performed on a preacher bench that emphasizes the lengthened position of the biceps.
instructions: Adjust bench so chest is flush against pad with armpits wedged in
Extend arms over pad and grip weight with underhand grip
Curl weight up, rotating pinkies toward ceiling
Stop before forearms are perpendicular to maintain tension
Lower weight below 90 degrees to emphasize lengthened position
tips: Emphasizes lengthened-position tension which is crucial for bicep growth
Keep elbows on pad throughout—lifting them invites shoulder flexion
Don't let weight rest on bench at any point during set
common_mistakes: Going to full perpendicular position (loses tension)
Using too much weight and cheating form

exercises.name: Concentration Curl
exercises.description: A seated biceps isolation exercise that eliminates momentum and emphasizes peak contraction.
instructions: Sit on bench with dumbbell between legs
Place upper arm (triceps) against inner thigh with arm perpendicular to ground
Make fist with opposite hand and extend to side for balance
Curl dumbbell up with control, keeping wrist neutral
Squeeze biceps hard at top without leaning back, then lower slowly
tips: Wedge upper arm into thigh, not just elbow
Upper arm should stay perpendicular to ground throughout
Emphasize squeeze at top for peak biceps development
common_mistakes: Wedging elbow instead of upper arm into thigh
Curling too high causing triceps to lose thigh contact

exercises.name: Incline Dumbbell Curl
exercises.description: A biceps curl performed on an incline bench that maximizes stretch on the long head of the biceps.
instructions: Set bench to 45-60 degree incline and sit with back against pad
Hold dumbbells with arms hanging behind body, palms facing forward
Keep upper arms stationary and curl dumbbells toward shoulders
Squeeze biceps at top of movement
Lower slowly with control to maximize eccentric stretch
tips: 45-degree angle provides optimal stretch on long head of biceps
Arms behind body creates greater range of motion than standing curls
Longer eccentric portion enhances hypertrophy
common_mistakes: Letting upper arms move forward during curl

exercises.name: Tricep Pushdown (Cable)
exercises.description: A cable isolation exercise that targets all three heads of the triceps with constant tension.
instructions: Set cable pulley to high position and attach straight bar or rope
Stand facing machine with feet hip-width apart, slight knee bend
Grip attachment with elbows pinned to sides at 90 degrees
Push bar/rope down by extending only at elbows until arms are straight
Return to starting position with control
tips: Keep elbows tight to sides—they shouldn't move
Focus on tricep extension, not pressing with shoulders
Can use rope attachment for slightly different angle
common_mistakes: Allowing elbows to drift forward or flare out
Using shoulders and upper body to press weight
Not achieving full extension at bottom

exercises.name: Skull Crushers (Lying Tricep Extension)
exercises.description: A lying triceps exercise that builds mass by allowing heavy weight with focus on tricep extension.
instructions: Lie on flat bench with barbell or dumbbells held with arms perpendicular to chest
Grip EZ bar or dumbbells with hands at shoulder-width
Lower weight toward forehead by bending only at elbows
Extend arms back to starting position using triceps
Can lower above head for greater long head emphasis and constant tension
tips: EZ bar grip reduces wrist stress and emphasizes lateral head
Extending arms further back overhead targets long head more
Keep upper arms stationary throughout
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to sides
Moving upper arms instead of just forearms
Dropping weight too fast risking head injury

exercises.name: Overhead Tricep Extension (Dumbbell)
exercises.description: A triceps exercise performed overhead that emphasizes the long head of the triceps.
instructions: Stand or sit holding dumbbell overhead with both hands cupping one end
Extend arms fully overhead to starting position
Brace core and pull belly button toward pelvis
Lower dumbbell behind head by bending only at elbows
Extend arms back to starting position by squeezing triceps
tips: Keep upper arms stationary—only forearms should move
Can perform seated to reduce lower back stress
Standing version engages core more
common_mistakes: Allowing upper arms to move forward
Using too much weight and losing form

exercises.name: Dips (Tricep Focus)
exercises.description: A bodyweight exercise emphasizing the triceps through an upright body position.
instructions: Grip dip bars and lift to starting position with arms extended
Keep body upright with head facing forward
Extend legs downward and keep elbows close to body
Lower body by bending elbows until upper arms are parallel to floor
Press back up using triceps without fully locking elbows
tips: Upright torso maximizes tricep activation
Narrow grip emphasizes triceps more than wide grip
Don't go below 90-degree angle to protect shoulders
common_mistakes: Fully locking out elbows at top

exercises.name: Close-Grip Bench Press
exercises.description: A bench press variation with narrow grip that emphasizes triceps while still engaging chest.
instructions: Lie on flat bench and grip barbell with hands closer than shoulder-width
Position bar over chest with arms extended
Lower bar to mid-chest keeping elbows tucked close to sides
Press bar back up focusing on tricep extension
Lock out at top and repeat
tips: Keep elbows tucked at approximately 30-45 degrees from body
Don't grip too narrow as this can strain wrists
Excellent for building tricep mass and lockout strength
common_mistakes: Gripping too narrow causing wrist pain

exercises.name: Back Squat (Barbell)
exercises.description: A fundamental compound exercise where a barbell is positioned on the upper back while performing a squatting motion.
instructions: Position barbell on upper back/traps and step back from rack with feet shoulder-width apart
Keep chest up, core braced, and maintain neutral spine throughout
Push hips back and bend knees to lower until thighs are parallel to ground or below
Keep knees tracking in line with toes and maintain even weight distribution across feet
Drive through heels and midfoot to stand back up, squeezing glutes at top
tips: Keep your chest up and maintain a slight arch in lower back
Your knees should track in line with your toes, not caving inward
Depth should be at least parallel, but go as deep as mobility allows with good form
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back at the bottom
Rising onto toes or shifting weight forward
Not going deep enough or bouncing at the bottom

exercises.name: Front Squat (Barbell)
exercises.description: A squat variation with the barbell positioned on the front of the shoulders, emphasizing quads and requiring greater core stability.
instructions: Position barbell on front of shoulders in the rack position with elbows high
Step back with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly pointed out
Keep torso upright and core braced throughout the movement
Descend by bending knees and hips simultaneously until thighs are parallel or below
Drive through entire foot to stand back up maintaining upright torso position
tips: Keep elbows as high as possible to prevent bar from rolling forward
Front squats demand greater thoracic mobility and upright posture than back squats
Use cross-arm grip if full rack position is uncomfortable
common_mistakes: Dropping elbows which causes torso to lean forward

exercises.name: Goblet Squat
exercises.description: A beginner-friendly squat variation holding a dumbbell or kettlebell at chest level.
instructions: Hold dumbbell or kettlebell vertically at chest level with both hands under the top weight
Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed slightly out
Keep chest up and core engaged as you push hips back and bend knees
Lower until thighs are parallel to ground while keeping elbows inside knees
Drive through feet to return to starting position, squeezing glutes at top
tips: Front-loaded position naturally keeps torso upright and core engaged
Use elbows to push knees out at the bottom for better depth
Excellent teaching tool for proper squat mechanics

exercises.name: Leg Press
exercises.description: A machine-based exercise that allows heavy loading of the legs with back support.
instructions: Sit in leg press machine with back flat against pad and feet shoulder-width apart on platform
Release safety bars and extend legs without locking knees
Slowly lower platform by bending knees until they reach 90 degrees or slightly below
Keep back flat against pad and avoid lifting hips during descent
Press through entire foot to extend legs back to starting position
tips: Foot placement affects muscle emphasis: higher = more glutes/hamstrings, lower = more quads
Wide stance targets inner thighs and glutes more
Never lock out knees completely at top
common_mistakes: Letting hips lift off the pad (increases injury risk)
Going too deep causing lower back to round

exercises.name: Leg Extension
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that targets the quadriceps using a leg extension machine.
instructions: Sit on machine with back against pad and adjust leg pad so it sits on lower shins
Grip handles on sides for stability
Extend legs by contracting quadriceps until legs are nearly straight
Pause briefly at top with quads fully contracted
Lower weight with control back to starting position
tips: Don't lock out knees completely to maintain constant tension
Control both the lifting and lowering phases
Point toes upward or slightly outward to maximize quad activation
common_mistakes: Using momentum or swinging the weight
Using too much weight and sacrificing form

exercises.name: Bulgarian Split Squat
exercises.description: A unilateral leg exercise with the rear foot elevated on a bench or platform.
instructions: Stand 2-4 feet in front of bench with one foot resting on bench behind you, laces down
Feet should be hip-width apart for stability, not in a straight line
Lower body by bending front knee until it reaches 90 degrees and back knee nearly touches floor
Keep torso upright for quad emphasis or lean forward slightly for glute emphasis
Push through front foot to return to starting position
tips: Back leg is for balance only - push primarily through front leg
Front foot position: closer to bench = more quads, farther = more glutes
Maintain stable base by keeping feet hip-width apart, not on a tightrope
common_mistakes: Placing back foot directly behind front foot (reduces stability)
Pushing through back leg instead of front leg
Leaning too far forward or rising onto toes

exercises.name: Walking Lunges (Barbell)
exercises.description: A dynamic lunge variation performed while walking forward, building leg strength and balance.
instructions: Position barbell on upper back and stand with feet hip-width apart
Take a large step forward with one leg and lower hips until both knees are at 90 degrees
Front knee should be aligned with ankle, back knee hovering just above floor
Push through front heel to bring back leg forward into next lunge
Continue alternating legs in a walking motion for desired distance or reps
tips: Maintain firm heel contact on front foot throughout movement
Keep chest up and core braced for stability
Step length should allow 90-degree angles at both knees at bottom
common_mistakes: Taking too short or too long steps
Allowing front knee to collapse inward
Touching back knee to ground forcefully

exercises.name: Step-ups
exercises.description: A unilateral exercise stepping onto an elevated platform to develop leg strength and balance.
instructions: Stand facing box or bench with entire foot of working leg planted on platform
Drive through working leg to step up onto platform, keeping torso upright
Fully extend hip and knee at top, bringing other foot to meet working leg or hover
Lower down slowly with control using non-working leg
Reset and repeat for all reps before switching legs
tips: Box height should allow front knee to bend at 90 degrees or slightly below
Push through the heel of elevated foot, not the back leg
Higher box emphasizes glutes more; lower box targets quads
common_mistakes: Using back leg to push up instead of front leg
Allowing front knee to cave inward
Dropping down quickly instead of controlling descent

exercises.name: Hack Squat (Machine)
exercises.description: A machine-based squat variation that isolates the quads while minimizing lower back stress.
instructions: Position back against pad with shoulders under shoulder pads
Place feet shoulder-width apart on platform with toes slightly pointed out
Release safety handles and extend legs to starting position
Lower sled by bending knees and hips until knees reach 90 degrees or slightly lower
Push through entire foot to drive platform back to starting position
tips: Keep entire back in contact with pad throughout movement
Foot placement affects emphasis: lower = more quads, higher = more glutes/hams
Drive through mid-foot and heels, not just toes
common_mistakes: Lifting lower back off pad during descent

exercises.name: Romanian Deadlift (RDL)
exercises.description: A hip-hinge exercise that primarily targets the hamstrings and glutes through controlled lowering.
instructions: Stand holding barbell at hip level with overhand grip, feet hip-width apart
Maintain slight knee bend and brace core with neutral spine
Hinge at hips by pushing them back and lowering bar down front of legs
Lower until you feel deep stretch in hamstrings, typically just below knees
Drive hips forward and squeeze glutes to return to standing position
tips: Keep bar close to body throughout - it should drag along shins and thighs
Focus on hip hinge not squat - shins should stay mostly vertical
Think about 'shutting a car door with your butt' as you hinge back
common_mistakes: Rounding the back instead of maintaining neutral spine
Bending knees too much (turns into squat)
Letting bar drift away from body
Not achieving full stretch in hamstrings

exercises.name: Stiff-Leg Deadlift
exercises.description: A deadlift variation with straighter legs that maximally stretches the hamstrings.
instructions: Stand with barbell at hip level, feet hip-width apart with minimal knee bend
Keep legs nearly straight with only slight bend in knees throughout
Hinge at hips to lower bar toward floor while maintaining flat back
Lower until maximum hamstring stretch is achieved without rounding back
Reverse movement by contracting hamstrings and glutes to stand upright
tips: Straighter legs than RDL create greater hamstring stretch
Maintain neutral spine - don't round to get lower
Hamstring flexibility determines how low you can go safely
common_mistakes: Rounding lower back to reach further down
Not maintaining tension in hamstrings throughout

exercises.name: Lying Leg Curl
exercises.description: An isolation exercise using a machine to target the hamstrings through knee flexion.
instructions: Lie face down on leg curl machine with pad positioned on lower calves
Grip handles for stability and ensure hips stay on pad
Curl legs by bending knees and bringing heels toward glutes
Squeeze hamstrings at top of movement
Lower weight with control back to starting position without fully extending
tips: Keep hips pressed against pad - don't lift them during curl
Point toes down or keep feet flexed for variation
Control the eccentric (lowering) portion for maximum benefit
common_mistakes: Lifting hips off pad to curl more weight
Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Seated Leg Curl
exercises.description: A machine-based hamstring isolation exercise performed in a seated position.
instructions: Sit on machine and adjust pad so it sits on lower calves
Position thigh pad securely over thighs and grip handles
Curl legs down by pulling heels toward glutes
Squeeze hamstrings at bottom of movement
Slowly return to starting position maintaining tension
tips: Seated position puts more emphasis on lower hamstrings
Keep upper body stable against back pad
Focus on hamstring contraction, not just moving weight
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and partial range of motion
Jerking the weight down with momentum

exercises.name: Good Mornings
exercises.description: A hip-hinge movement with barbell on back that develops hamstrings, glutes, and lower back strength.
instructions: Position barbell on upper back as in a squat, feet hip to shoulder-width apart
Brace core and maintain slight arch in lower back throughout
Hinge at hips by pushing them back with slight knee bend
Lower torso until nearly parallel to floor while maintaining neutral spine
Drive hips forward to return to standing position
tips: Think about pushing hips back like closing a door with your butt
Keep slight knee bend but shins should stay mostly vertical
Maintain tight core and neutral spine - never round the back
common_mistakes: Rounding the lower back during descent
Bending knees too much (becomes a squat)
Looking up instead of maintaining neutral neck
Using too much weight before mastering form

exercises.name: Nordic Hamstring Curl
exercises.description: An advanced bodyweight exercise that develops eccentric hamstring strength by controlling forward descent.
instructions: Kneel on pad with ankles secured by partner or anchor
Keep body in straight line from knees to shoulders with core braced
Slowly lower torso forward using hamstrings to control descent
Lower as far as possible with control before using hands to catch yourself
Push off floor with hands to return to starting position
tips: Focus on eccentric (lowering) portion - this builds tremendous hamstring strength
Use assistance from partner or bands if needed when starting out
Proven to significantly reduce hamstring injury risk
common_mistakes: Breaking at hips instead of maintaining straight body line
Dropping too quickly without controlling descent

exercises.name: Hip Thrust (Barbell)
exercises.description: The premier glute-building exercise involving hip extension with shoulders elevated on a bench.
instructions: Sit on floor with upper back against bench, barbell over hips with pad for comfort
Plant feet flat on floor hip to shoulder-width apart
Drive through heels to lift hips until body forms straight line from shoulders to knees
Squeeze glutes hard at top with chin tucked and ribs down
Lower hips with control and repeat without touching ground between reps
tips: Keep chin tucked to prevent lower back hyperextension
Push knees out slightly to maximize glute activation
Produces higher glute activation than squats or deadlifts
common_mistakes: Hyperextending lower back instead of using glutes
Not achieving full hip extension at top
Pushing through toes instead of heels

exercises.name: Hip Thrust (Single Leg)
exercises.description: A unilateral hip thrust variation that addresses muscle imbalances and increases glute activation.
instructions: Sit with upper back against bench, one foot planted and other leg extended
Drive through planted heel to lift hips while keeping other leg straight
Extend hips until body forms straight line with extended leg parallel to ground
Squeeze glute of working leg at top
Lower with control and repeat for all reps before switching legs
tips: Keep hips level - don't let them rotate to one side
Extended leg should stay straight and aligned with torso
Excellent for correcting strength imbalances between sides
common_mistakes: Rotating hips instead of keeping them square
Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Glute Bridge
exercises.description: A foundational hip extension exercise performed lying on the floor.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent and feet flat on floor hip-width apart
Place arms at sides or across chest
Engage core and drive through heels to lift hips toward ceiling
Squeeze glutes hard at top until body forms straight line from knees to shoulders
Lower hips back down with control without fully resting on floor
tips: Focus on glute contraction rather than just lifting hips
Can be weighted by placing barbell or dumbbell across hips
Excellent warm-up or activation exercise
common_mistakes: Pushing through toes instead of heels

exercises.name: Cable Kickback
exercises.description: An isolation exercise using cables to target the glutes through hip extension.
instructions: Attach ankle strap to low cable pulley and secure around working ankle
Face machine and hold on for support with slight forward hip hinge
Keep core engaged and hips squared forward throughout
Extend working leg straight back by contracting glutes, pushing through heel
Squeeze glutes at peak then return leg with control maintaining tension
tips: Keep hips squared - don't rotate them as you kick back
Push through heel not toes for better glute activation
Maintain slight forward lean from hips for optimal position

exercises.name: Sumo Deadlift
exercises.description: A wide-stance deadlift variation that emphasizes the glutes, quads, and adductors.
instructions: Stand with feet wide (1.5-2x shoulder width) and toes pointed out 30-45 degrees
Grip barbell with hands inside legs at shoulder-width, arms hanging straight down
Drop hips lower than conventional deadlift with more upright torso
Brace core and drive through feet to lift bar while keeping it close to body
Stand fully upright by extending hips and knees, squeeze glutes at top
tips: Wider stance reduces range of motion and emphasizes quads/glutes over hamstrings
Keep knees tracking over toes - push them out during ascent
Torso should be more upright than conventional deadlift
common_mistakes: Taking stance too wide beyond hip mobility limits
Starting with hips too low or too high
Pulling with arms instead of pushing through legs

exercises.name: Frog Pumps
exercises.description: A glute isolation exercise performed with soles of feet together in a butterfly position.
instructions: Lie on back with soles of feet together and knees dropped out to sides
Position feet close to glutes in butterfly position
Drive through outer edges of feet to lift hips toward ceiling
Squeeze glutes hard at top of movement
Lower hips back down and repeat for high reps
tips: Excellent for glute activation and high-rep pump work
Keep soles of feet pressed together throughout
Can be weighted with dumbbell or barbell across hips

exercises.name: Clamshells (Banded)
exercises.description: A glute medius activation exercise using a resistance band around the thighs.
instructions: Lie on side with hips and knees bent, resistance band around thighs above knees
Stack hips and shoulders vertically with feet together
Keep feet together and open top knee as high as possible against band resistance
Squeeze glute medius at top position
Lower knee with control and repeat for all reps before switching sides
tips: Keep hips stacked - don't let them roll back
Movement should come from hip rotation, not tilting pelvis
Essential for hip stability and injury prevention
common_mistakes: Using momentum instead of controlled movement
Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Standing Calf Raise
exercises.description: A fundamental calf exercise targeting the gastrocnemius muscle.
instructions: Stand on edge of step or platform with balls of feet, heels hanging off
Keep legs straight with just slight knee bend throughout
Rise up onto toes as high as possible by contracting calves
Hold peak contraction briefly
Lower heels below platform level for full stretch before next rep
tips: Full range of motion is crucial - from deep stretch to high peak
Standing calf raises emphasize gastrocnemius more than seated
Can perform single-leg for greater intensity and balance challenge
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion at top or bottom
Bouncing at bottom instead of controlled stretch
Bending knees which shifts emphasis to soleus

exercises.name: Seated Calf Raise
exercises.description: A calf exercise performed seated that emphasizes the soleus muscle.
instructions: Sit on machine with balls of feet on platform and knees under pad
Release safety and let heels drop for full stretch
Push through balls of feet to raise heels as high as possible
Squeeze calves at top position
Lower heels slowly back to stretched position
tips: Bent knee position targets soleus more than gastrocnemius
Soleus is important for calf development and often undertrained
Use full range of motion for maximum benefit
common_mistakes: Using too much weight and sacrificing range of motion

exercises.name: Donkey Calf Raise
exercises.description: A calf exercise performed in a bent-over position for maximum stretch and calf activation.
instructions: Lean forward at hips onto bench or support with torso roughly parallel to floor
Position balls of feet on edge of platform with heels hanging off
Have partner sit on lower back or use weight belt for resistance
Rise up onto toes as high as possible
Lower heels for deep stretch and repeat
tips: Bent-over position allows greater range of motion than standing raises
Excellent for overall calf development
Keep knees straight throughout movement
common_mistakes: Not achieving full stretch at bottom

exercises.name: Single Leg Calf Raise
exercises.description: A unilateral calf raise that builds strength and addresses muscle imbalances.
instructions: Stand on one leg with ball of foot on edge of step, other leg bent behind
Hold onto support for balance with one hand, optional dumbbell in other
Lower heel below step level for maximum stretch
Rise up onto toes as high as possible
Complete all reps before switching to other leg
tips: Challenges balance and strengthens ankle stability
Helps identify and correct strength imbalances between legs
Start without weight until balance is mastered
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion
Gripping support too tightly instead of using for balance only

exercises.name: Conventional Deadlift
exercises.description: The king of compound exercises, lifting a barbell from the floor using the entire posterior chain.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, barbell over midfoot
Hinge at hips and grip bar just outside legs with arms straight
Lower hips with chest up, back flat, and shoulders over or slightly ahead of bar
Brace core, engage lats, and push floor away with feet to lift bar
Stand fully upright with hips and knees locked, then lower bar with control
tips: Keep bar close to body throughout - drag it up shins and thighs
Think 'push the floor away' rather than 'pull the bar up'
Maintain neutral spine - never round the back
common_mistakes: Rounding the back at any point
Starting with hips too low or too high
Letting bar drift away from body
Not maintaining full-foot contact with ground

exercises.name: Trap Bar Deadlift (Hex Bar)
exercises.description: A deadlift variation using a hexagonal bar that allows for a more quad-dominant pulling position.
instructions: Stand in center of trap bar with feet hip-width apart
Hinge at hips and grip handles at sides with neutral grip
Lower hips with chest up and back flat until handles are at hand level
Brace core and drive through feet to stand upright
Lower bar back to ground with control and reset
tips: Neutral grip and centered weight reduces stress on lower back
More quad-dominant than conventional deadlift
Excellent for those with mobility limitations or back issues
common_mistakes: Not standing in exact center of bar
Letting weight shift forward or backward

exercises.name: Barbell Lunges (Reverse)
exercises.description: A lunge variation stepping backward that emphasizes glutes while being easier on the knees.
instructions: Position barbell on upper back and stand with feet hip-width apart
Step one leg backward and lower hips until both knees are at 90 degrees
Front knee should align with ankle, back knee hovering above floor
Push through front heel to return to starting position
Alternate legs or complete all reps on one side before switching
tips: Reverse lunges are generally easier on knees than forward lunges
Keep torso upright and core braced throughout
Front knee should not travel past toes
common_mistakes: Allowing front knee to collapse inward
Not achieving 90-degree angles at both knees

exercises.name: Sled Push
exercises.description: A functional full-body exercise pushing a weighted sled that emphasizes legs and conditioning.
instructions: Load sled with appropriate weight and grip handles at chest or shoulder height
Lean forward with body at 45-degree angle and core braced
Drive through legs with powerful strides, pushing sled forward
Maintain forward lean and continue pushing for desired distance
Keep arms extended and drive with legs, not by pushing with arms
tips: Lower handle position = more horizontal drive and quad emphasis
Higher handle position = more upright posture
Excellent for building leg strength without eccentric stress
common_mistakes: Standing too upright which reduces power output
Pushing with arms instead of driving with legs
Taking too short or choppy steps

exercises.name: Burpees (Standard)
exercises.description: A full-body explosive exercise combining a squat, plank, push-up, and jump in one continuous movement.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Lower into squat and place hands on floor in front of you
Jump feet back into plank position and perform a push-up (optional for beginners)
Jump feet back toward hands and explosively jump up reaching arms overhead
Land softly and immediately go into next rep
tips: Land softly with knees bent to reduce joint impact
Keep core engaged throughout entire movement
Focus on quality over speed when learning
common_mistakes: Not maintaining straight body during plank phase

exercises.name: Burpees (Modified)
exercises.description: A lower-impact burpee variation that steps back instead of jumping, making it more accessible for beginners.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Squat down and place hands on floor
Step one foot back at a time into plank position
Step feet forward one at a time back to squat
Stand up or add small jump if comfortable
tips: Perfect for those new to HIIT or with joint concerns
Focus on maintaining plank position
Gradually progress to full burpees as strength improves

exercises.name: Mountain Climbers
exercises.description: A dynamic core and cardio exercise alternating knees toward chest from plank position.
instructions: Start in high plank position with hands under shoulders
Keep body in straight line from head to heels
Quickly drive right knee toward chest while keeping core tight
Immediately switch legs bringing left knee forward as right extends back
Continue alternating legs rapidly as if running in place
tips: Keep hips level and in line with body, not piking up
Maintain stable upper body throughout
Start slower to master form then increase speed
common_mistakes: Letting shoulders drift forward past wrists
Not driving knees far enough forward

exercises.name: Jump Squats
exercises.description: An explosive lower body plyometric exercise adding a jump to the traditional squat.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Lower into squat with thighs parallel to ground
Explosively jump up driving through heels and extending hips
Reach arms overhead during jump
Land softly with knees bent absorbing impact and immediately lower into next squat
tips: Land with soft knees to protect joints
Focus on explosive upward movement
Keep chest up throughout movement
common_mistakes: Landing with locked or straight knees
Not descending deep enough in squat
Allowing knees to cave inward on landing

exercises.name: Jumping Lunges
exercises.description: A plyometric lunge variation that explosively switches legs mid-air.
instructions: Start in lunge position with both knees at 90 degrees
Explosively jump up switching legs mid-air
Land softly in lunge position with opposite leg forward
Immediately jump again to continue alternating
Keep torso upright and core engaged throughout
tips: Focus on controlled landings before increasing speed
Keep front knee aligned with ankle
Use arm swing to help with momentum and balance

exercises.name: High Knees
exercises.description: A high-intensity running-in-place exercise driving knees up toward chest.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Drive right knee up toward chest to hip level
Quickly switch bringing left knee up as right foot lands
Pump arms in running motion
Continue alternating at rapid pace maintaining upright posture
tips: Land on balls of feet for quick transitions
Keep core engaged and chest up
Aim to bring knees to hip height or higher
common_mistakes: Leaning back instead of staying upright

exercises.name: Tuck Jumps
exercises.description: An advanced plyometric jump bringing knees toward chest at the peak.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart
Bend knees slightly and swing arms back
Explosively jump up pulling knees toward chest
Quickly extend legs before landing
Land softly with bent knees and immediately repeat
tips: Focus on maximal height in jump
Pull knees up rather than bending forward
Land with soft knees to absorb impact
common_mistakes: Bending at waist instead of tucking knees
Not allowing adequate recovery between jumps

exercises.name: Plyo Push-ups
exercises.description: An explosive push-up variation where hands leave the ground during the upward phase.
instructions: Start in push-up position with hands slightly wider than shoulders
Lower chest toward ground rapidly with control
Explosively push up with enough force that hands leave ground
Land softly with hands in push-up position and immediately lower into next rep
Maintain tight core throughout movement
tips: Master regular push-ups before attempting plyometric version
Focus on explosive upward force
Advanced variation includes clapping hands while airborne
common_mistakes: Not achieving enough height to clear hands

exercises.name: Star Jumps
exercises.description: An explosive full-body jump forming a star shape at the peak with arms and legs extended.
instructions: Start in slight squat position with feet together
Explosively jump up extending arms and legs out to form star shape
Reach maximum extension at peak of jump
Bring arms and legs back together before landing
Land softly with bent knees and repeat
tips: Focus on full body extension at peak
Land with control absorbing impact through legs
Maintain rhythm for continuous reps

exercises.name: Squat Thrusts
exercises.description: A burpee without the push-up or jump, focusing on the plank transition.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart
Squat down and place hands on floor
Jump or step feet back to plank position
Immediately jump or step feet back to hands
Return to standing and repeat
tips: Keep core tight during plank position
Can be performed at high speed for cardio
Great progression toward full burpees

exercises.name: Speed Skaters
exercises.description: A lateral plyometric exercise mimicking a speed skating motion.
instructions: Start standing on right leg with left leg behind you
Jump laterally to left landing on left foot
Bring right leg behind left in skating motion
Immediately jump back to right side
Continue alternating sides with fluid skating motion
tips: Focus on lateral power and distance
Keep chest up and core engaged
Land with soft knee on each jump
common_mistakes: Not bringing back leg behind for balance

exercises.name: Kettlebell Swings
exercises.description: A powerful hip-hinge movement swinging kettlebell from between legs to shoulder height.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, kettlebell on ground in front
Hinge at hips and grip kettlebell with both hands
Hike kettlebell back between legs with straight arms
Explosively drive hips forward squeezing glutes to swing kettlebell to shoulder height
Let kettlebell swing back down between legs and repeat
tips: Power comes from hip drive, not arms
Keep spine neutral throughout movement
Arms should be like ropes connecting you to kettlebell
common_mistakes: Using arms to lift instead of hip drive

exercises.name: Box Jumps
exercises.description: A plyometric exercise jumping onto an elevated platform.
instructions: Stand facing box with feet shoulder-width apart
Bend knees and swing arms back
Explosively jump onto box landing with soft knees and full feet on platform
Stand fully upright on box
Step down carefully one foot at a time and repeat
tips: Start with lower box height and progress gradually
Land softly with knees bent to reduce impact
Step down rather than jumping down to protect joints
common_mistakes: Jumping down from box (increases injury risk)
Landing on edge of box with heels hanging off
Not achieving full hip extension at top

exercises.name: Battle Rope Slams
exercises.description: An explosive full-body exercise slamming both ropes to the ground simultaneously.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding rope ends
Get into quarter squat position with core braced
Raise both ropes overhead
Forcefully slam ropes down to ground using entire body
Immediately lift ropes and repeat with explosive power
tips: Use legs and core, not just arms
Focus on explosive power with each slam
Maintain athletic stance throughout
common_mistakes: Using only arms instead of full body

exercises.name: Battle Rope Waves
exercises.description: An alternating arm movement creating continuous waves through the ropes.
instructions: Hold rope ends with overhand grip, thumbs on rope
Stand in quarter squat with feet shoulder-width apart
Rapidly alternate raising and lowering each arm creating waves
Keep elbows tucked in close to body
Maintain consistent rhythm and wave height
tips: Focus on endurance and consistency over power
Keep core engaged and back neutral
Start with 30-second intervals
common_mistakes: Letting elbows flare out to sides

exercises.name: Medicine Ball Slams
exercises.description: An explosive overhead throw slamming medicine ball into ground.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart holding medicine ball
Raise ball overhead extending body upward
Forcefully slam ball to ground in front of feet using entire body
Catch ball on bounce or pick up and immediately repeat
Engage core throughout movement
tips: Use non-bounce ball for maximum force absorption
Drive through legs and core for power
Keep back straight when picking up ball
common_mistakes: Using only arms instead of full body
Rounding back when picking up ball

exercises.name: Thrusters
exercises.description: A combination of front squat and overhead press performed as one fluid movement.
instructions: Hold dumbbells at shoulder height or barbell in front rack position
Perform full squat keeping chest up and elbows high
Drive explosively through heels to stand
Use momentum from legs to press weight overhead to full extension
Lower weight to shoulders and immediately descend into next squat
tips: Use leg drive to help with overhead press
Keep core braced throughout
Move fluidly from squat to press without pausing
common_mistakes: Pressing with arms only instead of using leg momentum

exercises.name: Man Makers
exercises.description: A complex movement combining burpee, push-up, and dumbbell row.
instructions: Stand holding dumbbells at sides
Place dumbbells on ground and jump feet back to plank on dumbbells
Perform push-up then row one dumbbell to hip
Row other dumbbell to hip
Jump feet to hands, stand and perform dumbbell clean to shoulders, then press overhead
tips: Keep core tight throughout entire movement
Use hexagonal dumbbells for stability
Master each component before combining

exercises.name: Devil Press
exercises.description: A brutal full-body movement combining burpee with double dumbbell snatch.
instructions: Start with dumbbells on ground, perform burpee with hands on dumbbells
At top of burpee, explosively deadlift dumbbells
Continue momentum swinging dumbbells between legs
Drive hips forward and pull dumbbells overhead in one motion
Lower dumbbells and repeat
tips: Extremely demanding - use appropriate weight
Focus on hip drive for overhead movement
Breathe rhythmically throughout
common_mistakes: Not using hip power for overhead movement

exercises.name: Marching in Place
exercises.description: A gentle low-impact cardio exercise lifting knees alternately while stationary.
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Lift right knee to comfortable height while swinging left arm forward
Lower right foot and immediately lift left knee with right arm forward
Continue alternating in steady marching rhythm
Keep chest up and core engaged
tips: Perfect for warm-ups or active recovery
Can increase intensity by lifting knees higher
Maintain upright posture throughout

exercises.name: Step Touches
exercises.description: A side-to-side stepping movement that's gentle on joints.
instructions: Start with feet together
Step right foot out to side
Tap left foot beside right foot
Step left foot out to side
Tap right foot beside left and repeat
tips: Add arm movements to increase intensity
Keep steps wide for more challenge
Maintain steady rhythm

exercises.name: Low Impact Jacks
exercises.description: A modified jumping jack stepping side to side instead of jumping.
instructions: Start with feet together and arms at sides
Step right foot out to side while raising arms overhead
Step right foot back to center while lowering arms
Step left foot out to side while raising arms overhead
Continue alternating sides
tips: Great alternative to jumping jacks for joint protection
Can increase pace as cardiovascular fitness improves
Keep movements smooth and controlled
common_mistakes: Holding breath instead of breathing rhythmically

exercises.name: Standing Knee Raises
exercises.description: A controlled single-leg movement raising knee toward chest while standing.
instructions: Stand tall with feet hip-width apart
Raise right knee toward chest to hip height
Lower right foot with control
Raise left knee toward chest
Continue alternating at controlled pace
tips: Focus on balance and control
Can hold onto support if needed
Engage core to maintain stability
common_mistakes: Not lifting knee to adequate height

exercises.name: Boxer Shuffle
exercises.description: A quick-footed side-to-side shuffling movement maintaining athletic stance.
instructions: Stand in athletic stance with knees slightly bent
Shift weight to right foot while left foot taps ground
Quickly shift weight to left foot while right foot taps
Continue quick shuffling motion staying light on feet
Keep hands up in boxing guard position
tips: Stay on balls of feet
Keep knees soft and springy
Maintain rhythm and flow

exercises.name: Arm Circles with March
exercises.description: Combining marching in place with large arm circles for full-body warm-up.
instructions: Begin marching in place with controlled knee lifts
Extend arms out to sides at shoulder height
Make large forward circles with arms while continuing to march
After 15-20 seconds, reverse direction making backward circles
Maintain steady marching pace throughout
tips: Perfect warm-up exercise
Keep circles large and controlled
Coordinate breathing with movement

exercises.name: Side Steps
exercises.description: A lateral stepping movement traveling side to side.
instructions: Start with feet together
Step right foot out to side
Bring left foot to meet right
Continue stepping to right for several steps
Reverse direction stepping to left
tips: Keep knees slightly bent throughout
Stay low in athletic stance for more challenge
Can add arm movements for intensity

exercises.name: Grapevine
exercises.description: A classic aerobic step pattern crossing feet while traveling laterally.
instructions: Step right foot to right side
Cross left foot behind right
Step right foot to right again
Tap left foot beside right
Reverse pattern traveling to left
tips: Start slowly to master pattern
Add arm movements once comfortable
Keep movements fluid and rhythmic
common_mistakes: Moving too quickly before mastering pattern

exercises.name: Jumping Jacks
exercises.description: A classic total-body cardio exercise jumping feet out while raising arms overhead.
instructions: Start standing with feet together and arms at sides
Jump feet out to shoulder-width while raising arms overhead
Jump feet back together while lowering arms to sides
Maintain steady rhythm
Land softly on balls of feet
tips: Keep movements controlled and rhythmic
Land softly to protect joints
Engage core throughout

exercises.name: Shadow Boxing
exercises.description: Throwing punches and defensive moves against imaginary opponent for cardio conditioning.
instructions: Stand in boxing stance with feet staggered and knees bent
Keep hands up protecting face
Throw various punches (jabs, crosses, hooks, uppercuts)
Move feet incorporating footwork and defensive moves
Maintain constant movement for duration
tips: Focus on form over speed initially
Engage core with every punch
Stay light on feet and keep moving

exercises.name: Jump Rope (Basic)
exercises.description: A classic cardio exercise jumping over rotating rope.
instructions: Hold rope handles with hands at hip level
Position rope behind feet
Swing rope overhead and jump as it approaches feet
Land softly on balls of feet with slight knee bend
Maintain steady rhythm rotating from wrists
tips: Jump only high enough to clear rope
Keep elbows close to body
Start with shorter intervals building endurance
common_mistakes: Rotating from shoulders instead of wrists

exercises.name: Rowing Machine
exercises.description: A full-body cardio machine mimicking rowing motion with sliding seat.
instructions: Sit on rower with feet strapped in and knees bent (catch position)
Lean forward slightly with arms extended gripping handle
Drive through legs first, then lean back, finally pull handle to lower ribs
Reverse the motion: extend arms, lean forward, bend knees
Maintain smooth rhythm in ratio legs-core-arms, arms-core-legs
tips: Power comes 60% from legs, 20% core, 20% arms
Keep wrists flat when pulling handle
Maintain steady breathing rhythm
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms first instead of driving with legs
Bending knees before arms fully extend on recovery

exercises.name: Stationary Bike
exercises.description: A seated cardio machine providing low-impact cardiovascular exercise.
instructions: Adjust seat height so knee has slight bend at bottom of pedal stroke
Place feet in pedals or toe cages
Start pedaling maintaining steady cadence
Adjust resistance to target desired intensity
Keep upper body relaxed with slight forward lean
tips: Maintain cadence between 80-100 RPM for moderate intensity
Keep core engaged for stability
Excellent low-impact cardio option
common_mistakes: Seat too high or too low
Pedaling with just toes instead of full foot

exercises.name: Elliptical
exercises.description: A low-impact cardio machine with gliding motion engaging upper and lower body.
instructions: Step onto foot pedals and grip handles
Begin pushing and pulling handles while moving feet in elliptical motion
Maintain upright posture with core engaged
Adjust resistance and incline for desired intensity
Keep steady rhythm throughout workout
tips: Zero-impact on joints makes it excellent for recovery days
Push through heels to engage glutes more
Can reverse direction to target different muscles
common_mistakes: Moving only legs and not using arm motion
Going on toes instead of keeping feet flat

exercises.name: Stair Climbing
exercises.description: Climbing stairs or using stair machine for lower body cardio workout.
instructions: Step onto machine or approach stairs
Place full foot on each step
Drive through heel and midfoot to lift body
Maintain upright posture with light grip on rails for balance only
Keep steady climbing pace
tips: Don't lean heavily on rails - use for balance only
Take full steps placing entire foot on each stair
Excellent for building lower body strength and endurance

exercises.name: Swimming Strokes (Air)
exercises.description: Mimicking swimming motions on land for cardio and shoulder conditioning.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart and slight forward lean
Perform freestyle arm rotations alternating arms in swimming motion
Can also perform breaststroke by extending arms forward then pulling back
Add marching or small jumps for lower body involvement
Maintain fluid continuous movement
tips: Focus on full range of motion in shoulders
Keep core engaged throughout
Great active recovery or warm-up exercise
common_mistakes: Moving too slowly without cardio benefit

exercises.name: Mountain Pose (Tadasana)
exercises.description: The foundational standing pose that establishes proper alignment and creates a blueprint for all other yoga poses.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart or big toes touching, distributing weight evenly across both feet
Engage thighs, lift kneecaps, and rotate inner thighs slightly inward
Lengthen tailbone toward floor while lifting crown of head toward ceiling
Roll shoulders back and down, palms facing forward or at sides
Hold for 5-10 breaths, maintaining steady gaze and quiet breath
tips: Ground through all four corners of each foot
Imagine a string pulling the crown of your head upward
This pose teaches the foundation for proper alignment
common_mistakes: Leaning weight into heels or toes instead of center

exercises.name: Warrior I (Virabhadrasana I)
exercises.description: A powerful standing pose that builds strength in the legs while opening the chest and hips.
instructions: From standing, step right foot forward 3-4 feet, turn left foot out 45 degrees
Square hips forward keeping both hip points facing front of mat
Bend right knee to 90 degrees, keeping knee over ankle
Raise arms overhead with palms facing each other or touching
Hold for 5-10 breaths, maintaining upright torso and lifted chest
tips: Press firmly through outer edge of back foot
Keep front knee tracking over ankle, not collapsing inward
Lift from the sternum to avoid arching lower back
common_mistakes: Letting front knee collapse inward past big toe
Allowing hips to open to side instead of squaring forward
alternatives: Warrior I with hands on hips

exercises.name: Warrior II (Virabhadrasana II)
exercises.description: A foundational standing pose that builds stamina and concentration while strengthening legs and opening hips.
instructions: Stand with feet wide apart (4-5 feet), turn right foot out 90 degrees, left foot slightly in
Align right heel with left arch, open hips and torso to face side of mat
Bend right knee to 90 degrees, keeping thigh parallel to floor
Extend arms out to sides at shoulder height, gaze over front fingertips
Hold for 5-10 breaths, keeping torso stacked evenly over hips
tips: Stack shoulders directly over hips, not leaning forward or back
Press outer edge of back foot firmly into mat
Keep front knee aligned with ankle and second toe
common_mistakes: Front knee drifting inward past big toe
Shoulders hunching or arm dropping below shoulder height

exercises.name: Warrior III (Virabhadrasana III)
exercises.description: A challenging balancing pose that strengthens the entire body while enhancing focus and stability.
instructions: From standing, shift weight onto right leg and hinge forward at hips
Lift left leg behind you as you lower torso forward creating one line
Extend arms forward by ears or alongside body, palms facing each other
Bring body parallel to floor with standing leg slightly bent
Hold for 5-8 breaths, maintaining straight line from fingertips to back heel
tips: Keep hips level and squared to floor, not opening to side
Engage core strongly to maintain balance
Gaze down at floor to keep neck in neutral alignment
common_mistakes: Opening lifted hip toward ceiling instead of keeping hips square
Lifting head to look forward straining neck
Hyperextending standing leg instead of keeping soft bend
alternatives: Warrior III with hands on blocks

exercises.name: Triangle Pose (Trikonasana)
exercises.description: A standing pose that stretches the sides of the body while strengthening legs and improving balance.
instructions: Stand with feet wide, turn right foot out 90 degrees, left foot slightly in
Extend arms out to sides at shoulder height
Reach right hand forward, then hinge at hip to lower hand to shin, ankle, or block
Extend left arm straight up creating one line from bottom to top hand
Hold for 5-10 breaths, rotating chest toward ceiling and gazing up at top hand
tips: Keep both legs straight with engaged quadriceps
Lengthen spine rather than collapsing into bottom side
Rotate chest and belly toward ceiling, not down toward floor
common_mistakes: Leaning forward instead of maintaining length through both sides of torso
Straining neck by forcing gaze upward if uncomfortable

exercises.name: Extended Side Angle (Utthita Parsvakonasana)
exercises.description: A lateral stretch that strengthens legs, opens hips, and lengthens the side body.
instructions: From Warrior II with right leg forward, lower right forearm to right thigh
Extend left arm overhead creating diagonal line from left foot to left fingertips
Option to bring right hand to floor inside or outside right foot
Rotate chest toward ceiling and gaze under top arm
Hold for 5-8 breaths, maintaining strength in both legs
tips: Keep front knee at 90 degrees aligned with ankle
Lengthen through entire side body from outer edge of back foot through top fingertips
Can use block under bottom hand for support
common_mistakes: Dropping top shoulder forward instead of opening chest

exercises.name: Chair Pose (Utkatasana)
exercises.description: A powerful standing pose that builds heat and strengthens the entire lower body.
instructions: Stand with feet together or hip-width apart
Bend knees deeply as if sitting back into a chair
Raise arms overhead alongside ears with palms facing each other
Shift weight into heels keeping knees behind toes
Hold for 5-10 breaths, maintaining lifted chest and engaged core
tips: Sit hips back as if reaching for a chair behind you
Keep knees aligned with ankles, not extending past toes
Draw shoulder blades down back to avoid neck tension
common_mistakes: Leaning too far forward with weight in toes
Knees collapsing inward instead of tracking over feet

exercises.name: Standing Forward Fold (Uttanasana)
exercises.description: A calming forward bend that stretches the entire back body and can relieve tension.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, hands on hips
Inhale to lengthen spine, exhale to hinge forward from hips
