Let arms hang down or hold opposite elbows
Bend knees generously if hamstrings are tight
Hold for 5-10 breaths, letting head and neck relax completely
tips: Bend knees as much as needed to release lower back
Engage quadriceps to help hamstrings release
Let head hang heavy to release neck and shoulders
common_mistakes: Rounding from upper back instead of hinging from hips

exercises.name: Tree Pose (Vrksasana)
exercises.description: A foundational balancing pose that cultivates focus while strengthening legs and core.
instructions: Stand on left leg, place right foot on inner left thigh, calf, or ankle (not knee)
Press foot into leg and leg into foot with equal pressure
Bring hands to heart center or extend arms overhead
Find a focal point to help maintain balance
Hold for 5-10 breaths, then switch sides
tips: Start with foot at ankle or calf before attempting thigh placement
Engage standing leg strongly to maintain stability
Use wall support when learning
common_mistakes: Placing foot directly on knee joint
Shifting hips to side instead of keeping level
Holding breath instead of breathing steadily

exercises.name: Eagle Pose (Garudasana)
exercises.description: A challenging balance pose that wraps arms and legs while opening shoulders and hips.
instructions: Stand on left leg, cross right thigh over left and hook right foot behind left calf if possible
Cross left arm over right at elbows, bend elbows and press palms together
Sink hips back as if sitting in chair while maintaining wrapped position
Lift elbows to shoulder height and draw shoulder blades down
Hold for 5-8 breaths, maintaining balance and deep hip sink
tips: Focus on sinking hips low rather than perfect wrap
If foot won't hook, simply cross thighs
Squeeze arms and legs together to create stability
common_mistakes: Staying too upright instead of sinking hips back
Losing balance by not engaging core

exercises.name: Half Moon Pose (Ardha Chandrasana)
exercises.description: An intermediate balancing pose that strengthens legs and core while opening hips and chest.
instructions: From Triangle Pose, bend front knee and place hand on floor or block
Shift weight onto front leg and lift back leg parallel to floor
Stack top hip over bottom hip, rotating chest toward ceiling
Extend top arm straight up creating line from bottom to top hand
Hold for 5-8 breaths, gazing up at top hand if comfortable
tips: Use block under bottom hand to maintain length in spine
Keep standing leg micro-bent, not locked
Actively flex lifted foot to engage leg muscles
common_mistakes: Rolling top hip forward instead of stacking over bottom hip

exercises.name: Dancer's Pose (Natarajasana)
exercises.description: An advanced balance pose combining backbend and hip opening with graceful extension.
instructions: Stand on left leg, bend right knee bringing heel toward glute
Reach back with right hand to grasp outside of right foot or ankle
Extend left arm forward and up at shoulder height
Kick foot into hand while hinging slightly forward to create backbend
Hold for 5-8 breaths, maintaining balance and lifted chest
tips: Keep pelvis neutral, not tilting to side
Focus on kicking back leg into hand rather than forcing bend
Use strap around foot if you can't reach it
common_mistakes: Collapsing standing leg and not engaging it
Arching from lower back instead of upper back

exercises.name: Standing Hand to Big Toe (Utthita Hasta Padangusthasana)
exercises.description: A challenging balance pose that stretches hamstrings while building leg and core strength.
instructions: Stand on left leg, bend right knee and hold big toe with first two fingers
Slowly straighten right leg forward while maintaining upright posture
Option to open leg out to side or use strap around foot
Keep standing leg strong with slight bend in knee
Hold for 5-8 breaths, maintaining steady gaze and breath
tips: Use strap if you can't reach foot comfortably
Keep both hips level and squared forward
Maintain length in spine rather than rounding forward
common_mistakes: Lifting shoulder to ear on extended leg side

exercises.name: Pigeon Pose (Eka Pada Rajakapotasana)
exercises.description: A deep hip opener that stretches the hip flexors, glutes, and piriformis muscles.
instructions: From Downward Dog, bring right knee forward behind right wrist
Slide left leg back with top of foot on mat, square hips forward
Walk hands forward or stay upright depending on hip opening
Option to fold forward over front leg if hips allow
Hold for 10-15 breaths, breathing into any areas of tightness
tips: Place block or blanket under front hip if it doesn't touch ground
Keep back leg straight and extended, not turning out
Breathe deeply to help muscles release
common_mistakes: Forcing front hip down causing knee strain
Letting hips rotate to side instead of squaring forward

exercises.name: Lizard Pose (Utthan Pristhasana)
exercises.description: A powerful hip opener that deeply stretches hip flexors, hamstrings, and groin.
instructions: From Downward Dog, step right foot forward outside of right hand
Lower back knee to mat or keep it lifted for more intensity
Walk right foot to outer edge of mat, turning toes slightly out
Lower onto forearms if hip flexibility allows, or stay on hands
Hold for 8-12 breaths, keeping front knee aligned with ankle
tips: Use blocks under hands or forearms to make pose more accessible
Keep front knee tracking over second toe, not collapsing inward
Option to tuck back toes and lift knee for active variation
common_mistakes: Sinking into shoulders instead of maintaining length

exercises.name: Frog Pose (Mandukasana)
exercises.description: An intense hip opener that targets the inner thighs and groin.
instructions: Start on hands and knees, slowly widen knees out to sides
Keep ankles in line with knees, feet turned out
Lower onto forearms and gradually widen knees as far as comfortable
Keep hips aligned with knees, not drifting forward or back
Hold for 10-20 breaths, breathing into hips and inner thighs
tips: Place blanket under knees for cushioning
Move slowly and mindfully, never forcing the stretch
This pose can be very intense, listen to your body
common_mistakes: Widening knees too far too quickly
Letting hips drift forward past knees

exercises.name: Bound Angle Pose (Baddha Konasana)
exercises.description: A seated hip opener that stretches the inner thighs and groin while promoting relaxation.
instructions: Sit with legs extended, bend knees and bring soles of feet together
Draw heels toward pelvis and let knees fall open to sides
Hold feet or ankles with hands
Lengthen spine upward or fold forward from hips
Hold for 10-15 breaths, allowing knees to gradually release toward floor
tips: Place blocks or blankets under knees if they're far from floor
Sit on blanket or block to elevate hips if needed
Don't force knees down, let gravity do the work
common_mistakes: Pulling feet too close causing strain
Pushing down on knees with hands

exercises.name: Happy Baby (Ananda Balasana)
exercises.description: A gentle supine hip opener that stretches the inner thighs and lower back.
instructions: Lie on back, bend knees and draw them toward chest
Hold outside edges of feet with hands (or use strap)
Open knees wider than torso and draw them toward armpits
Flex feet with soles facing ceiling, keep ankles over knees
Hold for 10-15 breaths, gently rocking side to side if desired
tips: Keep lower back pressing into mat
Use strap if you can't reach feet comfortably
Can do one leg at a time for modification
common_mistakes: Lifting head and shoulders off mat straining neck

exercises.name: Fire Log Pose (Agnistambhasana)
exercises.description: An intense seated hip opener that stacks shins to deeply open hips and stretch glutes.
instructions: Sit with legs crossed, stack right shin directly over left shin
Align right ankle over left knee and right knee over left ankle
Flex both feet to protect knees
Sit upright or fold forward from hips
Hold for 10-15 breaths, then switch leg stacking
tips: Place block between shins if knees are stacked high
Flex feet strongly to protect knee joints
This pose can be very intense, move slowly
common_mistakes: Letting feet sickle instead of keeping them flexed
Forcing knees down instead of allowing gravity

exercises.name: Cobra Pose (Bhujangasana)
exercises.description: A gentle backbend that strengthens the spine and opens the chest and shoulders.
instructions: Lie face down with hands under shoulders, elbows bent and close to ribs
Press tops of feet and thighs into mat
Inhale to lift chest using back muscles, keeping elbows bent
Draw shoulder blades down back and lift through sternum
Hold for 5-8 breaths, keeping lower body grounded
tips: Use back muscles more than arm strength
Keep elbows bent unless doing Upward Dog variation
Engage legs to protect lower back
common_mistakes: Overarching lower back by lifting too high

exercises.name: Upward Dog (Urdhva Mukha Svanasana)
exercises.description: A dynamic backbend that strengthens arms and spine while opening chest and shoulders.
instructions: From Cobra, press tops of feet firmly into mat
Straighten arms to lift thighs and hips off mat
Only hands and tops of feet touch floor
Roll shoulders back, lift chest, and gaze slightly upward
Hold for 3-5 breaths before transitioning to next pose
tips: Keep legs and glutes engaged to support lower back
Arms should be straight unlike Cobra where elbows bend
Draw shoulder blades down back to create space
common_mistakes: Hyperextending neck by looking too far up

exercises.name: Bridge Pose (Setu Bandhasana)
exercises.description: A moderate backbend that strengthens legs and back while opening chest and shoulders.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent, feet hip-width apart near glutes
Press feet firmly into mat and lift hips toward ceiling
Interlace fingers under back or keep arms alongside body
Roll shoulders under to lift chest toward chin
Hold for 5-10 breaths, keeping knees aligned over ankles
tips: Keep knees tracking over ankles, not splaying out
Engage glutes and hamstrings to lift hips
Can place block under sacrum for supported variation
common_mistakes: Letting knees splay out wider than hips
Overarching neck by tucking chin too much
Not engaging legs and letting hips sag

exercises.name: Wheel Pose (Urdhva Dhanurasana)
exercises.description: An advanced full backbend that builds strength and flexibility throughout the entire body.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent, feet hip-width apart near glutes
Place hands by ears with fingers pointing toward shoulders
Press into hands and feet to lift hips and crown of head off mat
Straighten arms to fully lift into backbend
Hold for 5-10 breaths, keeping legs parallel and feet grounded
tips: Warm up thoroughly with gentler backbends first
Keep feet parallel and knees from splaying out
Push strongly through arms and legs equally
common_mistakes: Letting feet and knees turn out
Dumping into lower back instead of evenly distributed bend

exercises.name: Camel Pose (Ustrasana)
exercises.description: A deep kneeling backbend that opens the entire front body including chest, abdomen, and hip flexors.
instructions: Kneel with knees hip-width apart, thighs perpendicular to floor
Place hands on lower back with fingers pointing down
Lift chest and begin to arch back, keeping hips over knees
Option to reach for heels with hands if comfortable
Hold for 5-8 breaths, lifting from sternum and engaging glutes
tips: Keep hips directly over knees throughout
Engage glutes and thighs to protect lower back
Can keep hands on lower back instead of reaching for heels
common_mistakes: Letting hips move backward instead of staying over knees
Dropping head back too far straining neck
Not engaging legs causing compression in lower back

exercises.name: Bow Pose (Dhanurasana)
exercises.description: A deep backbend that stretches the entire front body while strengthening the back.
instructions: Lie on belly, bend knees and reach back to hold outside of ankles
Inhale to lift chest and thighs off mat simultaneously
Kick feet into hands to deepen backbend
Gaze forward and breathe into chest
Hold for 5-8 breaths before releasing with control
tips: Kick legs actively into hands to lift higher
Keep knees hip-width apart, not wider
Engage back muscles rather than just pulling with arms
common_mistakes: Straining neck by looking up too much

exercises.name: Seated Forward Fold (Paschimottanasana)
exercises.description: A calming forward bend that deeply stretches the entire back body.
instructions: Sit with legs extended straight in front, feet flexed
Inhale to lengthen spine, exhale to hinge forward from hips
Reach for feet, shins, or use strap around feet
Keep spine long rather than rounding to reach farther
Hold for 10-15 breaths, relaxing deeper with each exhale
tips: Bend knees if needed to maintain length in spine
Focus on hinging from hips, not rounding from waist
Use strap if you can't reach feet comfortably
common_mistakes: Rounding spine to force hands to feet
Holding breath instead of breathing steadily

exercises.name: Head to Knee Pose (Janu Sirsasana)
exercises.description: A one-legged forward fold that stretches hamstrings and opens hips.
instructions: Sit with left leg extended, bend right knee bringing sole of foot to inner left thigh
Square shoulders toward extended leg
Inhale to lengthen, exhale to fold forward over straight leg
Hold foot, shin, or use strap, keeping spine long
Hold for 10-15 breaths, then switch sides
tips: Keep extended leg active with flexed foot
Square hips toward extended leg
Can bend extended knee slightly if hamstrings are tight
common_mistakes: Twisting toward bent knee instead of straight leg

exercises.name: Seated Twist (Ardha Matsyendrasana)
exercises.description: A seated spinal twist that improves spine mobility and aids digestion.
instructions: Sit with legs extended, bend right knee and place foot outside left thigh
Bend left knee bringing foot near right hip (or keep extended for easier variation)
Inhale to lengthen spine, exhale to twist right
Hook left elbow outside right knee, right hand behind on floor
Hold for 8-10 breaths, then switch sides
tips: Lengthen spine on each inhale, twist deeper on exhale
Keep both sit bones grounded
Twist from entire spine, not just shoulders
common_mistakes: Rounding spine instead of staying tall
Cranking twist with arm instead of rotating from core

exercises.name: Boat Pose (Navasana)
exercises.description: A core-strengthening pose that builds abdominal strength and hip flexor endurance.
instructions: Sit with knees bent, feet on floor, hands behind thighs
Lean back slightly and lift feet off floor bringing shins parallel to mat
Extend arms forward alongside legs, palms facing each other
Option to straighten legs creating V-shape with body
Hold for 5-10 breaths, keeping chest lifted and spine long
tips: Keep chest lifted to avoid rounding lower back
Engage core deeply to maintain balance
Start with bent knees before attempting straight legs

exercises.name: Staff Pose (Dandasana)
exercises.description: A foundational seated pose that builds postural awareness and core strength.
instructions: Sit with legs extended straight in front, feet flexed
Place hands on floor beside hips, fingers pointing forward
Press through heels and engage thighs
Lift chest and crown of head toward ceiling
Hold for 5-10 breaths, maintaining active engagement
tips: Sit on folded blanket if you tend to round lower back
Engage legs strongly as if doing standing mountain pose
Draw shoulder blades down back
common_mistakes: Leaning back instead of sitting upright

exercises.name: Cow Face Pose (Gomukhasana)
exercises.description: A seated pose that deeply stretches shoulders, arms, hips, and outer thighs.
instructions: Sit with knees stacked, right knee on top, feet beside opposite hips
Raise right arm overhead, bend elbow bringing hand down back
Bring left arm behind back, bend elbow and reach up to clasp right hand
Sit tall and breathe into areas of tightness
Hold for 8-10 breaths, then switch sides
tips: Use strap between hands if they don't meet
Keep spine upright, don't lean forward or back
Can sit on blanket if hips are tight
common_mistakes: Leaning to one side instead of staying centered

exercises.name: Downward Dog (Adho Mukha Svanasana)
exercises.description: A foundational inversion that strengthens arms and legs while stretching the entire back body.
instructions: Start on hands and knees, hands shoulder-width apart
Curl toes under and lift hips up and back creating inverted V-shape
Press firmly through palms with fingers spread wide
Work to straighten legs and press heels toward floor
Hold for 5-10 breaths, keeping head relaxed between arms
tips: Bend knees if needed to maintain length in spine
Press shoulder blades toward back ribs
Distribute weight evenly between hands and feet
common_mistakes: Rounding upper back instead of lengthening spine
Weight too far forward in hands

exercises.name: Dolphin Pose
exercises.description: A shoulder-strengthening inversion on forearms that prepares for headstand and forearm stand.
instructions: Start on hands and knees, lower to forearms with elbows under shoulders
Interlace fingers or keep forearms parallel
Curl toes and lift hips up creating inverted V on forearms
Walk feet toward elbows to bring shoulders over elbows
Hold for 5-8 breaths, keeping head off floor
tips: Keep elbows shoulder-width apart, not wider
Engage core to prevent sinking into shoulders
Excellent preparation for forearm balance
common_mistakes: Letting elbows splay wider than shoulders

exercises.name: Headstand (Sirsasana)
exercises.description: The king of yoga poses, an advanced inversion that builds strength, focus, and confidence.
instructions: Kneel and interlace fingers, place forearms on mat forming triangle
Place crown of head on mat with back of head in hands
Straighten legs and walk feet toward elbows
Engage core and lift one or both legs toward ceiling
Hold for 10-30 breaths once balanced, keeping neck relaxed
tips: Should only be practiced once you have strong foundation
Most weight should be in forearms, not head
Practice against wall when learning
common_mistakes: Putting too much weight in head/neck
Kicking up forcefully instead of controlled lift

exercises.name: Shoulder Stand (Sarvangasana)
exercises.description: The queen of yoga poses, an inversion that calms the nervous system while energizing the body.
instructions: Lie on back with folded blanket under shoulders (not under neck)
Bend knees and lift legs overhead into Plow Pose
Bend elbows and support back with hands
Lift legs straight up toward ceiling, bringing torso perpendicular to floor
Hold for 10-20 breaths, keeping neck still and gaze at chest
tips: Use blanket under shoulders to protect neck
Keep head and neck completely still
Most weight should be on shoulders and upper arms
common_mistakes: Turning head side to side while in pose
Not using blanket for neck protection
Collapsing into lower back instead of lifting through legs

exercises.name: Child's Pose (Balasana)
exercises.description: A restorative resting pose that gently stretches the back while calming the mind.
instructions: Kneel with big toes touching and knees wide or together
Sit hips back toward heels
Extend arms forward or rest alongside body
Rest forehead on mat or on stacked hands/block
Hold for 1-3 minutes, breathing deeply into back body
tips: Place blanket between hips and heels if uncomfortable
Can keep knees together or wide apart
Perfect rest pose between more active poses
common_mistakes: Forcing hips toward heels causing knee strain

exercises.name: Legs Up the Wall (Viparita Karani)
exercises.description: A gentle restorative inversion that reduces swelling in legs and calms nervous system.
instructions: Sit sideways against wall with one hip touching it
Swing legs up wall while lowering back to floor
Scoot hips as close to wall as comfortable
Rest arms out to sides or on belly
Hold for 5-15 minutes, breathing slowly and deeply
tips: Place folded blanket under hips for gentle backbend
Can move hips further from wall if hamstrings are tight
Excellent for evening relaxation and recovery
common_mistakes: Tensing legs instead of letting them relax
Hips too far from wall reducing benefits
Not staying long enough to receive calming effects

exercises.name: Corpse Pose (Savasana)
exercises.description: The final relaxation pose that integrates the practice and promotes deep rest and integration.
instructions: Lie on back with legs extended and feet falling naturally apart
Rest arms alongside body with palms facing up
Close eyes and release all effort from body
Let breath return to natural rhythm
Rest for 5-15 minutes, allowing complete relaxation
tips: Place blanket under knees if lower back is uncomfortable
Cover with blanket if room is cool
Most important pose - allows body to integrate practice
common_mistakes: Skipping this pose or cutting it short
Tensing body instead of completely releasing

exercises.name: Supine Twist (Supta Matsyendrasana)
exercises.description: A gentle restorative twist that releases tension in spine and hips.
instructions: Lie on back, draw right knee toward chest
Guide right knee across body to left side using left hand
Extend right arm out to side at shoulder height
Turn gaze toward right hand or keep looking up
Hold for 10-15 breaths, then switch sides
tips: Keep shoulders grounded, right shoulder may lift slightly
Place block or blanket under knee if it doesn't reach floor
Breathe into any areas of tightness
common_mistakes: Forcing knee to floor straining spine
Lifting opposite shoulder significantly off mat
Tensing instead of relaxing into twist

exercises.name: The Hundred
exercises.description: The quintessential Pilates exercise that builds core endurance, increases breath control, and warms up the entire body.
instructions: Lie on back, curl head and shoulders up, lift legs to tabletop position (knees bent 90 degrees) or extend to 45 degrees
Extend arms long by sides hovering just above mat, palms facing down
Pump arms vigorously up and down: inhale for 5 pumps, exhale for 5 pumps (one set)
Maintain deep core engagement with navel to spine, keep lower back imprinted into mat
Complete 10 sets for total of 100 arm pumps, then lower with control
tips: Scoop abs deeply to protect lower back throughout
Gaze toward navel to keep neck aligned with spine
Keep shoulder blades just grazing mat, not lifting too high
common_mistakes: Letting lower back arch off mat
Lifting from neck instead of chest

exercises.name: Roll Up
exercises.description: A fundamental spinal articulation exercise that strengthens abdominals while promoting flexibility through the spine.
instructions: Lie flat with arms overhead, legs extended together, feet flexed
Inhale: Float arms to ceiling, begin curling head and shoulders off mat
Exhale: Peel spine off mat one vertebra at a time, rolling forward reaching toward toes in C-curve
Inhale at top: Maintain C-curve with abs scooped, shoulders over hips
Exhale: Roll back down articulating through each vertebra, arms return overhead
tips: Maintain C-curve throughout entire movement, don't flatten spine
Use breath to assist abdominals, not momentum
Keep legs anchored and feet flexed strongly
common_mistakes: Using momentum to swing up instead of articulating
Straightening spine instead of maintaining C-curve

exercises.name: Roll Over
exercises.description: An advanced exercise that builds abdominal strength and spinal flexibility through controlled inversion.
instructions: Lie on back with legs extended to ceiling, arms pressing into mat by sides
Inhale: Engage abs and begin lifting hips, rolling spine off mat
Exhale: Continue rolling over until legs are parallel to floor overhead
Inhale: Open legs hip-width and flex feet
Exhale: Roll down one vertebra at a time, bring legs together at 45 degrees, repeat
tips: Press shoulders and arms firmly into mat for support
Control descent by articulating through each vertebra
Never roll onto neck - weight stays on shoulders
common_mistakes: Rolling too far onto neck causing strain

exercises.name: Single Leg Circles
exercises.description: An exercise that strengthens hip stabilizers while improving hip mobility and pelvic stability.
instructions: Lie on back, extend right leg to ceiling, left leg extended on mat or bent with foot flat
Inhale: Circle extended leg across body, down, and around (5 circles one direction)
Exhale: Complete circle back to starting position
Keep pelvis absolutely stable - no rocking or tilting
Switch directions for 5 circles, then switch legs
tips: Keep circles within range where pelvis stays completely still
Engage deep core to stabilize pelvis
Opposite hip stays grounded on mat
common_mistakes: Letting pelvis rock or tilt during circles
Making circles too large and losing stability
alternatives: Both knees bent for more support

exercises.name: Rolling Like a Ball
exercises.description: A playful exercise that massages the spine while building balance and abdominal control.
instructions: Sit balanced on tailbone, knees pulled into chest, hands holding shins or ankles
Lift feet off mat, find balance point in tight ball shape
Inhale: Roll back to shoulder blades keeping tight ball shape
Exhale: Use abs to roll back up to balanced starting position without feet touching
Repeat 6-10 times maintaining consistent ball shape
tips: Keep head tucked and gaze at navel throughout
Don't roll onto neck - stop at shoulder blades
Use momentum but control with abs
common_mistakes: Rolling onto neck instead of stopping at shoulders
Uncurling from ball shape during roll

exercises.name: Single Leg Stretch
exercises.description: A dynamic core exercise that builds abdominal endurance while coordinating breath and movement.
instructions: Lie on back in Pilates curl (head and shoulders lifted), pull right knee to chest, extend left leg to 45 degrees
Place right hand on right ankle, left hand on right knee
Exhale: Switch legs - pull left knee in as right extends
Switch hand positions with each leg change (outside hand to ankle, inside hand to knee)
Continue switching legs for 8-10 repetitions each side, maintaining lifted upper body
tips: Keep lower back pressed into mat - don't let it arch
Extend legs only as low as you can while maintaining imprinted spine
Pull knee straight toward shoulder, not to the side
common_mistakes: Extending leg too low causing back to arch

exercises.name: Double Leg Stretch
exercises.description: An advanced abdominal exercise that challenges core stability through full extension of arms and legs.
instructions: Start in Pilates curl with both knees pulled into chest, hands on ankles
Inhale: Extend arms overhead and legs forward to 45 degrees simultaneously
Exhale: Circle arms wide and sweep them around to return to ankles as knees pull back in
Maintain deep core engagement throughout - lower back stays imprinted
Repeat 8-10 times with fluid, coordinated movement
tips: Scoop abs deeply especially as limbs extend
Only extend legs as low as you can while keeping back flat
Keep head and shoulders lifted throughout
common_mistakes: Arching lower back as legs extend
alternatives: Legs to tabletop instead of extended

exercises.name: Spine Stretch Forward
exercises.description: A seated forward bend that lengthens the spine and stretches the back while maintaining core engagement.
instructions: Sit tall with legs extended hip-width apart, feet flexed, arms reaching forward at shoulder height
Inhale: Grow taller through crown of head
Exhale: Tuck chin and roll forward sequentially through spine creating C-curve
Reach arms forward past feet, scooping abs in deeply
Inhale: Stack spine back up one vertebra at a time to tall seated position
tips: Focus on lengthening spine rather than just reaching forward
Keep abs scooped in throughout
Flex feet strongly to engage legs
alternatives: Sit on block for tight hamstrings

exercises.name: Open Leg Rocker
exercises.description: A challenging balance exercise that builds core control while articulating through the spine.
instructions: Sit balancing on tailbone with legs extended in V-shape, holding outside of ankles
Inhale: Maintain C-curve and roll back to shoulder blades
Exhale: Use deep abs to roll back up to balanced starting position
Keep legs in V-position throughout, maintain strong core connection
Repeat 6-8 times without feet touching mat between reps
tips: Keep C-curve constant - don't let spine flatten
Use momentum but control with abdominals
Stop roll at shoulder blades, never onto neck

exercises.name: Saw
exercises.description: A seated twisting exercise that wrings out the lungs while stretching the back and hamstrings.
instructions: Sit tall with legs extended wider than mat, feet flexed, arms extended out to sides
Inhale: Twist torso to right from waist, keeping hips square
Exhale: Reach left hand past right little toe as if sawing it off, right arm reaches back
Pulse 3 times exhaling completely to wring out lungs
Inhale: Stack spine back up through twist, untwist to center, repeat other side
tips: Keep both sit bones grounded - don't let opposite hip lift
Twist from waist, not just reaching arm
Exhale completely with each pulse
common_mistakes: Rotating from shoulders instead of spine

exercises.name: Dead Bug
exercises.description: A core stabilization exercise that teaches pelvic control while moving opposite limbs.
instructions: Lie on back with arms extended to ceiling, knees in tabletop position
Press lower back into mat maintaining imprint throughout
Exhale: Extend right arm overhead and left leg forward simultaneously
Inhale: Return to starting position with control
Exhale: Switch sides - left arm and right leg extend. Repeat 8-10 each side
tips: Keep lower back glued to mat - this is the priority
Move slowly with precision and control
Only extend limbs as far as you can while keeping back flat

exercises.name: Bird Dog
exercises.description: A quadruped exercise that builds core stability, balance, and strengthens the back and glutes.
instructions: Start on hands and knees in neutral spine, shoulders over wrists, hips over knees
Engage core by drawing navel to spine
Exhale: Extend right arm forward and left leg back creating one line from fingertips to toes
Inhale: Hold position maintaining level hips and shoulders
Exhale: Return to start. Repeat 8-10 times each side
tips: Keep hips and shoulders square - no rotation
Maintain neutral spine - don't let lower back sag
Reach through crown of head to maintain neck alignment

exercises.name: Plank (Pilates Style)
exercises.description: A fundamental core strengthening hold emphasizing breath, alignment, and full-body integration.
instructions: Start on forearms and toes with body in straight line from head to heels
Draw navel to spine, engage glutes and legs
Inhale through nose for 5 counts, exhale through mouth for 5 counts
Maintain neutral spine - don't let hips sag or pike up
Hold for 30-60 seconds with continuous breath
tips: Think of creating opposition - reach heels back while crown extends forward
Keep shoulder blades flat on back, not winging out
Breathe continuously - never hold breath
common_mistakes: Hips sagging creating lower back arch

exercises.name: Side Plank
exercises.description: A lateral core strengthener that targets obliques and builds shoulder stability.
instructions: Lie on side with forearm under shoulder, legs extended and stacked
Inhale: Prepare by engaging core
Exhale: Lift hips creating straight line from head to heels
Top arm can extend to ceiling or rest on hip
Hold for 20-45 seconds breathing steadily, repeat other side
tips: Stack shoulders, hips, and ankles in one line
Lift through obliques, not just pushing through bottom arm
Engage entire bottom side of body
common_mistakes: Rolling forward or back instead of staying stacked
alternatives: Top leg in front for support

exercises.name: Criss Cross (Bicycle)
exercises.description: A dynamic oblique exercise that combines rotation with leg extension.
instructions: Lie in Pilates curl with hands behind head, elbows wide, both knees in tabletop
Exhale: Twist right, bringing right shoulder toward left knee as right leg extends
Hold twist and pulse for 2 counts
Inhale: Return to center
Exhale: Twist left bringing left shoulder to right knee, right leg extends. Repeat 8-10 each side
tips: Rotate from ribcage, not just moving elbow
Keep lower back imprinted throughout
Reach extended leg long at 45 degrees or higher
common_mistakes: Just moving elbow instead of rotating torso

exercises.name: Double Leg Lower Lift
exercises.description: An intense lower abdominal exercise that challenges core strength through leg lowering and lifting.
instructions: Lie on back with legs extended to ceiling at 90 degrees, hands behind head or by sides
Press lower back firmly into mat
Inhale: Lower both legs toward floor as far as you can while keeping back flat
Exhale: Use lower abs to lift legs back to 90 degrees
Repeat 8-10 times, never letting back arch off mat
tips: Only lower legs as far as you can maintain flat back
Scoop abs deeply especially as legs lower
Think of lengthening legs away rather than just lowering
common_mistakes: Lowering legs too far causing back to arch

exercises.name: Teaser I
exercises.description: The signature Pilates exercise building core strength, balance, and full-body control.
instructions: Lie on back with one knee bent (foot flat), other leg extended to 45 degrees
Inhale: Prepare with arms overhead
Exhale: Roll up articulating through spine, reaching arms forward parallel to extended leg
Balance on sit bones in V-position, shoulders over hips
Inhale: Roll back down with control. Repeat 5 times, switch legs
tips: Maintain C-curve in spine throughout
Keep extended leg reaching long and stable
Find balance point on sit bones

exercises.name: Scissors
exercises.description: A dynamic exercise that builds core endurance while stretching hamstrings and hip flexors.
instructions: Lie on back, lift both legs to ceiling, curl head and shoulders up
Gently pulse right leg toward face while left leg reaches away (double pulse)
Hands can lightly hold right calf or shin
Scissor legs to switch - left leg pulses toward face, right reaches away
Continue alternating for 8-10 each side, keeping hips stable
tips: Keep pelvis stable - don't let it rock side to side
Reach legs from hip, keeping them long
Maintain lifted upper body throughout

exercises.name: Cat-Cow (Pilates Breath)
exercises.description: A spinal mobility warm-up that articulates through the spine with coordinated breath.
instructions: Start on hands and knees in neutral spine, hands under shoulders, knees under hips
Inhale: Arch spine lifting chest and tailbone (cow), maintain core engagement
Exhale: Round spine tucking tailbone under, draw navel to spine deeply (cat)
Move segmentally through spine, initiating from tailbone
Repeat 8-10 times flowing with breath
tips: Move one vertebra at a time, not all at once
Maintain core engagement even in cow position
Coordinate breath with movement precisely
common_mistakes: Just moving head and hips without articulating spine

exercises.name: Spine Twist
exercises.description: A seated rotation exercise that mobilizes the spine while strengthening obliques.
instructions: Sit tall with legs extended together, arms out to sides at shoulder height
Inhale: Grow taller through spine
Exhale: Twist to right from waist in 2 pulses, keeping hips square
Inhale: Return to center
Exhale: Twist to left in 2 pulses. Repeat 5-6 times each side
tips: Sit on block if hamstrings tight
Keep both sit bones grounded
Lengthen spine as you twist
common_mistakes: Using arms to pull twist rather than rotating from core

exercises.name: Mermaid Stretch
exercises.description: A lateral spine stretch that opens the side body and promotes spinal mobility.
instructions: Sit with knees bent to side (mermaid position), right hand on mat by hip
Inhale: Reach left arm up and over to right, creating side bend
Exhale: Deepen stretch reaching further, feeling left ribs expand
Inhale: Return to upright
Add rotation: thread left arm under right side exhaling, return and repeat. Switch sides
tips: Keep both sit bones grounded
Reach up and over, not just to side
Breathe into stretched side
common_mistakes: Leaning forward or back instead of pure side bend

exercises.name: Swan Dive
exercises.description: An advanced rocking backbend that builds spinal extension strength and coordination.
instructions: Lie on stomach with hands by shoulders, legs together
Inhale: Press up into back extension (swan) keeping abs engaged
Exhale: Release arms to sides, rock forward lifting legs as chest lowers
Inhale: Rock back lifting chest as legs lower
Continue rocking 5-6 times maintaining arc shape, then lower with control
tips: Maintain core engagement to protect spine
Rock from center, not just throwing body
Keep movement controlled and rhythmic
common_mistakes: Hyperextending lower back without core support

exercises.name: Swimming
exercises.description: A back extension exercise that builds endurance in back muscles while improving coordination.
instructions: Lie on stomach with arms extended overhead, legs together
Hover arms, chest, and legs off mat maintaining neutral spine
Flutter opposite arm and leg (right arm/left leg, then left arm/right leg)
Inhale for 5 counts, exhale for 5 counts while continuing flutter
Complete 5-10 breath cycles, then lower with control
tips: Keep movement small and controlled
Lengthen through crown of head
Engage abs to protect lower back

exercises.name: Breast Stroke
exercises.description: A flowing back extension that mobilizes the spine while strengthening the posterior chain.
instructions: Lie on stomach with forehead on mat, arms extended forward
Inhale: Lift chest and arms, circle arms wide to sides like swimming breaststroke
Exhale: Reach arms back toward feet as chest lifts higher
Inhale: Return arms forward lowering chest back down
Repeat 6-8 times with flowing, continuous movement
tips: Keep abs engaged throughout to support spine
Move with fluid grace, not jerky motions
Coordinate breath with movement

exercises.name: Clamshells
exercises.description: A side-lying hip opener that strengthens gluteus medius and external hip rotators.
instructions: Lie on side with hips and knees bent to 90 degrees, heels together
Place optional resistance band around thighs just above knees
Exhale: Lift top knee keeping heels together, opening like clamshell
Inhale: Lower knee with control
Repeat 15-20 times, maintaining stable pelvis and core engagement
tips: Keep hips stacked - don't let pelvis roll back
Focus on hip rotation, not just lifting knee
Engage core to prevent movement in spine
common_mistakes: Tilting pelvis instead of pure hip rotation

exercises.name: Side-Lying Leg Series (Front/Back)
exercises.description: A series of leg movements that strengthen hips and glutes while challenging core stability.
instructions: Lie on side with bottom leg bent, top leg extended at hip height
Support head with bottom arm, top hand on mat in front for balance
Inhale: Sweep top leg forward flexing foot, keeping leg at hip height
Exhale: Point toe and sweep leg back past hip using glutes
Repeat 10 times, then reverse breathing pattern for 10 more, switch sides
tips: Keep hips and shoulders stacked - no rocking
Engage core deeply to keep torso stable
Movement comes from hip, not from tilting pelvis
common_mistakes: Rocking torso forward and back with leg
Letting leg drop below hip height

exercises.name: Bridge (Pilates Style)
exercises.description: A fundamental exercise that strengthens glutes and hamstrings while articulating the spine.
instructions: Lie on back with knees bent, feet hip-width apart near glutes, arms by sides
Inhale: Prepare, engage core
Exhale: Tilt pelvis and peel spine off mat one vertebra at a time
Create diagonal line from shoulders to knees at top
Inhale at top, exhale to roll spine back down articulating through each vertebra
tips: Articulate through spine - don't just lift all at once
Keep knees aligned over ankles, not splaying
Engage inner thighs and glutes at top
common_mistakes: Lifting too high into lower back arch

exercises.name: Single Leg Bridge
exercises.description: An advanced bridge variation that challenges balance and unilateral glute strength.
instructions: Start in bridge position with hips lifted
Extend right leg to ceiling keeping hips level
Inhale: Lower hips halfway down
Exhale: Press back up to bridge using left leg and glute
Repeat 8-10 times, switch legs
tips: Keep hips absolutely level - don't let them tilt
Press through standing foot heel
Maintain core engagement throughout

exercises.name: Kneeling Side Kicks
exercises.description: An advanced side-lying kick series performed in high kneeling position.
instructions: Kneel on mat, place right hand down and extend left leg to side at hip height
Left arm reaches overhead creating curve in spine
Exhale: Kick left leg forward with flexed foot
Inhale: Point toe and sweep leg back
Repeat 8-10 times maintaining balance, switch sides
tips: Keep hips stacked over knees
Engage core deeply for balance
Create length through extended leg

exercises.name: Quadruped Hip Circles
exercises.description: A mobility exercise that opens hips while maintaining core stability.
instructions: Start on hands and knees in neutral spine
Lift right knee off mat and circle it forward, out to side, back, and return
Complete 5 circles one direction, reverse for 5 circles
Keep pelvis and spine completely stable throughout
Switch legs and repeat
tips: Move only from hip joint
Keep supporting leg and pelvis absolutely still
Maintain neutral spine throughout

exercises.name: Push-up (Pilates Style)
exercises.description: A full-body exercise incorporating spinal articulation and core control.
instructions: Stand tall, inhale to prepare
Exhale: Roll down through spine to place hands on mat
Walk hands out to plank position
Perform 3-5 push-ups with elbows close to ribs, body in straight line
Walk hands back, roll spine up to standing one vertebra at a time
tips: Articulate through spine on way down and up
Keep body in one line during push-ups
Engage abs throughout entire sequence

exercises.name: Leg Pull Front
exercises.description: An advanced plank variation with leg lift that challenges total body integration.
instructions: Start in high plank position on hands, body in straight line
Inhale: Lift right leg up behind you keeping hips level
Exhale: Lower right leg and repeat with left
Continue alternating legs for 8-10 total lifts
Maintain strong core and stable shoulders throughout
tips: Keep hips and shoulders square and level
Press away from mat through shoulders
Engage glutes to lift leg, not just hip flexors

exercises.name: Leg Pull Back
exercises.description: A reverse plank with leg lifts that strengthens the posterior chain.
instructions: Sit with legs extended, hands behind hips fingers pointing toward feet
Lift hips creating reverse plank position
Inhale: Point right foot and lift leg toward ceiling
Exhale: Flex foot and lower leg. Repeat other side
Continue alternating for 8-10 lifts maintaining lifted hips
tips: Keep hips lifted high throughout
Press through heels and hands
Engage glutes and hamstrings

exercises.name: Side Bend
exercises.description: An advanced lateral balance exercise that strengthens obliques and shoulders.
instructions: Sit on right hip with legs together bent to side, right hand on mat
Inhale: Press up to side plank lifting hips, left arm sweeps overhead
Create arc from feet through fingertips
Exhale: Thread left arm under body rotating torso
Inhale: Return to side bend, repeat 3-5 times, switch sides
tips: Stack shoulders, hips, and feet
Lift from obliques
Maintain strong base arm

exercises.name: Twist
exercises.description: A dynamic seated rotation that mobilizes spine and strengthens obliques.
instructions: Sit tall with legs crossed, arms extended out to sides
Inhale: Lengthen through spine
Exhale: Twist to right from waist, right arm reaches back, left forward
Pulse twist 3 times exhaling completely
Inhale: Return center. Exhale: Twist left. Repeat 5-6 each side
tips: Keep both sit bones grounded
Initiate twist from deep core
Lengthen spine as you rotate

exercises.name: Control Balance
exercises.description: An advanced exercise combining flexibility, balance, and core control.
instructions: Lie on back, roll over bringing legs overhead (shoulder stand position)
Hold one ankle with both hands, extend other leg toward ceiling
Switch legs in air - release held leg as you catch the other
Continue switching legs 6-8 times with control
Roll down slowly to complete
tips: Balance on shoulders, not neck
Keep movement controlled and precise
Requires advanced flexibility and strength

exercises.name: Push-up (Standard)
exercises.description: The fundamental horizontal pushing movement that builds chest, shoulders, and triceps strength.
instructions: Start in plank position with hands slightly wider than shoulder-width, body in straight line
Lower chest to floor by bending elbows, keeping them at 45-degree angle to torso
Descend until chest nearly touches ground, maintaining tight core
Press through palms to return to starting position, repeat for desired reps
tips: Keep body in straight line from head to heels - no sagging hips
Engage core throughout entire movement
Breathe in on descent, breathe out on ascent
common_mistakes: Letting hips sag or pike up
Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Wide Push-up
exercises.description: A push-up variation with hands placed wider to emphasize chest activation.
instructions: Place hands 6-12 inches wider than shoulder-width in plank position
Lower body while keeping elbows tracking over wrists
Descend until chest is 1-2 inches from floor
Press back up maintaining wide hand position throughout
tips: This variation places more emphasis on outer chest
Keep core tight to prevent lower back arch
Don't go so wide that shoulder stability is compromised
common_mistakes: Hands too wide causing shoulder instability

exercises.name: Diamond Push-up
exercises.description: A narrow-grip push-up that significantly increases triceps activation.
instructions: Form diamond shape with hands by touching thumbs and index fingers together
Position hands directly under chest in plank position
Lower body keeping elbows close to sides
Press back up focusing on triceps engagement
tips: Keep elbows tucked close to body throughout movement
This is one of the best triceps bodyweight exercises
Progression toward archer and one-arm push-ups

exercises.name: Decline Push-up
exercises.description: An elevated-feet push-up that increases difficulty and upper chest activation.
instructions: Place feet on elevated surface 12-24 inches high
Assume push-up position with hands on ground
Lower chest to ground with controlled descent
Push back up maintaining elevated foot position
tips: Higher elevation increases difficulty and shoulder engagement
Progression toward pike push-ups and handstand push-ups
Maintain straight body line throughout

exercises.name: Archer Push-up
exercises.description: A unilateral push-up progression that loads one arm while the other assists.
instructions: Start in wide push-up position with hands 1.5-2x shoulder-width apart
Shift weight toward one arm while descending, keeping that elbow bent
Extend opposite arm straight out to side as you lower
Push back up to center, then repeat on other side
tips: Working arm should be in diamond push-up position
Extended arm provides minimal assistance
Key progression toward one-arm push-ups
common_mistakes: Not shifting enough weight to working arm
Rotating torso instead of staying square

exercises.name: Pseudo Planche Push-up
exercises.description: An advanced push-up with hands positioned by hips to mimic planche position.
instructions: Place hands by hips with fingers pointing toward feet
Lean shoulders forward past wrists while maintaining plank
Lower body while keeping forward lean
Push back up maintaining planche-lean position throughout
tips: Essential progression for planche training
Start with hands by ribs before moving to hips
Extreme shoulder and core engagement required

exercises.name: One-Arm Push-up Progression
exercises.description: Progressive steps toward performing a full one-arm push-up.
instructions: Start with archer push-ups to build unilateral strength
Progress to assisted one-arm (other hand on basketball or elevated surface)
Widen stance for better balance and stability
Gradually reduce assistance until performing full one-arm push-up
tips: Feet wider than shoulders helps with balance
Keep hips square to ground, minimal rotation
Takes months to years to achieve

exercises.name: Planche Push-up
exercises.description: The ultimate horizontal push - a push-up performed from full planche position.
instructions: Achieve full planche position with body parallel to ground
Lower body slightly by bending arms while maintaining horizontal position
Press back up to full planche lock-out
Requires years of specific strength training to achieve
tips: Master planche hold for 10+ seconds first
Start with tuck planche push-ups
One of the most difficult bodyweight exercises

exercises.name: Pike Push-up
exercises.description: A vertical pushing movement that targets shoulders and prepares for handstand push-ups.
instructions: Start in downward dog position with hips high, forming inverted V-shape
Place hands shoulder-width apart, feet 3-4 feet behind hands
Lower head toward ground by bending elbows, sending head forward of hands
Press back up to starting position, keeping hips high throughout
tips: Head should travel forward and down, not straight down
Nose should touch ground for full range of motion
Key progression to handstand push-ups
common_mistakes: Lowering head between hands instead of forward

exercises.name: Wall Handstand Hold
exercises.description: A foundational inversion hold that builds shoulder strength and body awareness.
instructions: Place hands 6-12 inches from wall, kick up into handstand with heels against wall
Stack shoulders over wrists, engage core to prevent lower back arch
Look between hands keeping neutral neck position
Hold for time, building up to 60 seconds
tips: Chest should face wall, not back to wall initially
Focus on straight body line with engaged core
Foundation for all handstand work

exercises.name: Wall Handstand Push-up
exercises.description: A vertical pushing movement performed in handstand position against wall.
instructions: Kick up into wall handstand with chest facing wall
Lower head toward ground by bending elbows
Descend until head lightly touches floor
Press back up to full lockout
tips: Master 45-60 second wall handstand hold first
Use deficit (hands on parallettes) for increased range
Breathe at top of movement

exercises.name: Freestanding Handstand
exercises.description: An unsupported handstand requiring balance, strength, and body awareness.
instructions: From standing, place hands on ground and kick up to handstand
Find balance point by making micro-adjustments with fingers and shoulders
Maintain straight body line with engaged core
Hold for time, working up to 30+ seconds
tips: Master wall handstand hold for 60 seconds first
Practice chest-to-wall handstand for proper alignment
Takes months of consistent practice
common_mistakes: Giving up too quickly on balance attempts

exercises.name: Handstand Push-up (Freestanding)
exercises.description: The ultimate vertical push - a push-up performed in freestanding handstand.
instructions: Kick up or press up into freestanding handstand
Maintain balance while lowering head toward ground
Touch head to ground lightly
Press back up while maintaining balance throughout
tips: Requires mastery of freestanding handstand first
Start with wall handstand push-ups
One of the most difficult bodyweight pressing movements

exercises.name: 90-Degree Push-up
exercises.description: An advanced bent-arm strength hold where body is parallel to ground.
instructions: From plank position, lean forward significantly past wrists
Lower into push-up position until upper arms are parallel to ground
Hold this position with body parallel to floor
Maintain extreme forward lean and core tension
tips: Bridge between planche and handstand training
Requires significant shoulder and core strength
Start with short holds of 3-5 seconds

exercises.name: Dead Hang
exercises.description: A foundational hanging position that builds grip strength and shoulder stability.
instructions: Grasp pull-up bar with shoulder-width overhand grip
Hang with arms fully extended and body relaxed
Engage shoulders slightly to prevent complete relaxation
Hold for time, building up to 60+ seconds
tips: Foundation for all pulling movements
Builds critical grip strength
Active hang (shoulders engaged) vs passive hang

exercises.name: Scapular Pulls
exercises.description: An isolation exercise that teaches scapular retraction essential for pull-ups.
instructions: Hang from bar in dead hang position
Without bending elbows, depress and retract shoulder blades
Body should rise slightly (1-2 inches) from scapular movement alone
Lower back to dead hang and repeat
tips: Essential movement pattern for pull-up success
Focus on squeezing shoulder blades down and together
No elbow bend - all movement from shoulders
common_mistakes: Bending elbows instead of moving scapula
Not achieving full range of scapular motion

exercises.name: Chin-ups
exercises.description: A vertical pulling movement with underhand grip that emphasizes biceps.
instructions: Grasp bar with underhand (supinated) grip at shoulder-width
From dead hang, initiate pull by depressing scapula
Pull body up until chin clears bar
Lower with control back to full dead hang
tips: Generally easier than pull-ups due to bicep engagement
Full range of motion is critical
Good progression before overhand pull-ups
common_mistakes: Not achieving full lockout at bottom

exercises.name: Pull-ups
exercises.description: The fundamental vertical pulling movement with overhand grip.
instructions: Grasp bar with overhand (pronated) grip slightly wider than shoulders
Hang with arms fully extended, engage core
Pull body up leading with chest until chin clears bar
Lower with control to full dead hang
tips: Think about pulling elbows down and back
Maintain slight hollow body position
Cornerstone of calisthenics training
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Wide Grip Pull-ups
exercises.description: Pull-ups with wider grip that emphasizes lat width development.
instructions: Grasp bar with hands 6-12 inches wider than shoulder-width
From dead hang, pull body up focusing on lat engagement
Pull until upper chest approaches bar
Lower with control to full extension
tips: Reduces bicep involvement, increases lat activation
May need to reduce range initially
Builds back width
common_mistakes: Grip too wide causing shoulder issues

exercises.name: Archer Pull-ups
exercises.description: A unilateral pull-up variation that loads one arm significantly more.
instructions: Grasp bar with wide grip (1.5-2x shoulder-width)
Pull body toward one arm while extending opposite arm straight
Pull until working-side shoulder approaches hand
Lower and repeat on opposite side
tips: Key progression toward one-arm pull-ups
Extended arm provides minimal assistance
Maintain control throughout movement
common_mistakes: Not pulling far enough to working side

exercises.name: Typewriter Pull-ups
exercises.description: A dynamic pull-up variation alternating between archer positions at the top.
instructions: Pull up to top of bar with wide grip
While maintaining height, shift body toward right hand
Slide horizontally across bar to left hand
Lower down and repeat
tips: Stay at top of pull-up throughout horizontal movement
Great for building endurance and unilateral strength
Requires strong pull-up foundation

exercises.name: One-Arm Pull-up Progression
exercises.description: Progressive steps toward performing a full one-arm pull-up.
instructions: Master archer pull-ups with minimal assistance from extended arm
Progress to assisted one-arm (grab wrist or use towel)
Practice one-arm negatives (lower slowly from top)
Eventually perform full one-arm pull-up from dead hang to chin over bar
tips: Takes months to years to achieve
High strength-to-weight ratio required
One of calisthenics' ultimate pulling achievements
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Muscle-ups
exercises.description: A dynamic movement combining pull-up and dip in one explosive motion.
instructions: From dead hang, perform explosive pull-up pulling bar to waist level
Transition by rotating wrists and leaning forward over bar
Press down into dip position finishing with locked arms above bar
Lower with control back to dead hang
tips: Requires chest-to-bar pull-up strength and strong dip
False grip helps with transition
Explosive power essential for strict muscle-up

exercises.name: Australian Rows (Inverted Rows)
exercises.description: A horizontal pulling movement performed under a bar at waist height.
instructions: Position bar at waist height, lie underneath with body straight
Grasp bar with overhand grip at shoulder-width
Pull chest to bar by retracting shoulder blades and bending elbows
Lower with control maintaining straight body line
tips: Lower bar height increases difficulty
Great progression toward pull-ups
Keep body rigid like a plank throughout

exercises.name: Archer Rows
exercises.description: Unilateral horizontal row that shifts weight to one arm.
instructions: Set up as for Australian rows with wider grip
Pull body toward one arm while extending opposite arm
Pull until working-side shoulder approaches hand
Lower and repeat on other side
tips: Progression toward one-arm rows
Maintain straight body line
Control is key

exercises.name: Front Lever Raises
exercises.description: A dynamic movement raising body from dead hang toward front lever position.
instructions: From dead hang, engage lats and pull body backward
Raise legs toward horizontal while pulling shoulders down
Aim to achieve front lever position or highest point possible
Lower with control back to dead hang
tips: Start with tuck front lever raises
Focus on lat engagement, not just leg lift
Progression exercise for front lever hold

exercises.name: Front Lever
exercises.description: An advanced static hold with body horizontal in front of bar.
instructions: From dead hang, engage lats powerfully and raise legs
Achieve horizontal body position with arms straight
Maintain perfect straight line from head to toes
Hold position for time
tips: Progress through tuck, advanced tuck, straddle, then full
Requires exceptional lat and core strength
Can take 1-2 years of specific training

exercises.name: Bench Dips
exercises.description: A beginner dipping movement using a bench or chair.
instructions: Sit on edge of bench, place hands next to hips
Walk feet forward and lower hips off bench
Lower body by bending elbows to 90 degrees
Press back up to starting position
tips: Keep elbows tracking back, not flaring out
Feet further from bench increases difficulty
Good introduction to dipping movement
common_mistakes: Going too low causing shoulder strain
Using legs too much for assistance

exercises.name: Parallel Bar Dips
exercises.description: The fundamental dipping movement on parallel bars.
instructions: Jump or step into support position on parallel bars with arms locked
Lower body by bending elbows until shoulders are below elbows
Lean forward slightly for chest emphasis or stay upright for triceps
Press back up to full lockout
tips: Full range of motion is critical
Control descent to protect shoulders
Foundation for advanced dip variations

exercises.name: Ring Dips
exercises.description: An advanced dip variation on gymnastic rings requiring stabilization.
instructions: Mount rings and achieve stable support position with rings close to body
Lower body while actively turning rings out to prevent instability
Descend to full depth with shoulders below elbows
Press up powerfully while maintaining ring control
tips: Much harder than parallel bar dips due to instability
Turn rings out (RTO) position increases difficulty
Essential for ring training progression
common_mistakes: Allowing rings to move away from body

exercises.name: Korean Dips
exercises.description: An advanced dip variation with body behind the bars.
instructions: Start in support position, lean back and shift body behind bars
Maintain horizontal back position while performing dip
Lower by bending elbows while keeping body behind bars
Press back up maintaining posterior lean
tips: Requires exceptional shoulder flexibility and strength
Progress from regular dips first
Very advanced movement

exercises.name: Straight Bar Dips
exercises.description: Dips performed on a single straight bar requiring balance.
instructions: Jump or muscle-up to support position on top of bar
Balance on bar with hands pronated or in false grip
Lower body by bending elbows while maintaining balance
Press back up to support position
tips: Requires excellent balance and core control
False grip can help with stability
Foundation for more advanced bar skills

exercises.name: Impossible Dips
exercises.description: An extremely advanced dip where body passes through arms.
instructions: From dip support position, lower body forward through arms
Shift shoulders in front of hands while descending
Achieve position where body has passed through arm line
Press back up reversing the motion
tips: One of the most difficult dip variations
Requires extreme shoulder mobility and strength
Master Korean dips first

exercises.name: Bodyweight Squat
exercises.description: The fundamental lower body movement pattern.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly turned out
Lower body by bending knees and hips simultaneously
Descend until thighs are parallel to ground or deeper
Drive through heels to return to standing
tips: Keep chest up and core engaged throughout
Knees should track over toes, not cave inward
Foundation for all squatting movements

exercises.name: Jump Squat
exercises.description: An explosive plyometric squat variation.
instructions: Start in squat position with feet shoulder-width apart
Explosively jump upward driving through balls of feet
Extend fully through hips, knees, and ankles
Land softly and immediately descend into next rep
tips: Focus on soft landings to protect joints
Builds explosive power
Great for athletic performance

exercises.name: Sissy Squat
exercises.description: An advanced quad-dominant squat leaning backward.
instructions: Stand with feet hip-width apart, hold support for balance
Lean torso backward while bending knees forward
Lower body until shins are nearly parallel to ground
Rise back up maintaining backward lean
tips: Extreme quad isolation exercise
Requires good knee health
Start with partial range of motion

exercises.name: Shrimp Squat Progression
exercises.description: A single-leg squat holding rear foot behind body.
instructions: Stand on one leg, bend opposite knee bringing foot behind
Hold rear foot with hand on same side
Lower body by bending standing leg while descending
Touch rear knee to ground, then drive up to standing
tips: Alternative to pistol squat requiring less mobility
Excellent for quad and glute development
Progress from assisted versions

exercises.name: Pistol Squat Progression
exercises.description: Progressive steps toward performing a full single-leg squat.
instructions: Progress through: box pistols, assisted pistols with support, negative pistols
For full pistol: extend one leg forward, lower on other leg to full depth
Maintain extended leg parallel to ground throughout
Drive through heel to stand while keeping other leg extended
tips: Requires strength, mobility, and balance
Takes months of progressive training
One of the ultimate bodyweight leg exercises

exercises.name: Nordic Curl
exercises.description: An intense hamstring exercise lowering body forward from kneeling position.
instructions: Kneel with feet secured under immovable object or held by partner
Keep body straight from knees to head, cross arms over chest
Slowly lower torso forward by eccentrically resisting with hamstrings
Catch yourself with hands and push back to start
tips: One of the best hamstring exercises
Focus on slow eccentric phase
May need to use hands significantly at first
common_mistakes: Breaking at hips instead of staying straight

exercises.name: Hollow Body Hold
exercises.description: A fundamental core position creating total body tension.
instructions: Lie on back, press lower back into floor
Lift shoulders and legs off ground creating banana shape
Arms can extend overhead or by sides
Hold position maintaining lower back contact with floor
tips: Foundation position for gymnastics and calisthenics
Essential for proper body alignment
If back arches, raise legs higher or bend knees
common_mistakes: Allowing lower back to arch off floor

exercises.name: L-Sit Progression
exercises.description: Progressive steps toward holding an L-sit position.
instructions: Progress from: foot-supported L-sit, one-leg L-sit, tuck L-sit
For full L-sit: support body on hands with straight arms
Lift legs to horizontal position with straight knees
Hold position maintaining compression and straight arms
tips: Parallettes make it easier than floor
Requires hip flexor and core strength
Foundation for V-sit and more advanced skills

exercises.name: V-Sit
exercises.description: An advanced core hold with legs raised higher than L-sit.
instructions: From seated position, lift legs toward ceiling at 45+ degrees
Balance on sit bones with arms supporting on sides or extended forward
Create V-shape with body
Hold position with control
tips: Requires extreme hip flexor and core strength
Greater compression than L-sit
Foundation for more advanced compression work
common_mistakes: Using arms too much for support

exercises.name: Dragon Flag
exercises.description: An advanced core exercise where body is lowered and raised while suspended from shoulders.
instructions: Lie on bench, grip behind head for anchor point
Raise entire body until only shoulders remain on bench
Lower body with control maintaining straight line
Descend as low as possible without back touching bench, then raise
tips: One of the most difficult core exercises
Start with negative-only reps
Made famous by Bruce Lee
common_mistakes: Bending at hips instead of staying straight

exercises.name: Human Flag Progression
exercises.description: Progressive steps toward holding body horizontal from a vertical pole.
instructions: Progress from: flag plank with foot support, low flag, high flag, angled flag
Then: tuck flag, one-leg flag, straddle flag, full flag
Bottom arm pushes, top arm pulls to create stability
Achieve horizontal body position parallel to ground
tips: One of the most visually impressive skills
Requires months to years of training
Each progression should be held 15-20 seconds before advancing

exercises.name: Back Lever
exercises.description: A static hold with body horizontal behind the bar.
instructions: From inverted hang, lower body backward toward horizontal
Achieve position with back facing ground, body straight
Arms remain straight throughout
Hold position for time
tips: Progress through: tuck, advanced tuck, straddle, then full
Generally easier than front lever
Excellent for developing straight-arm strength

exercises.name: Front Lever (Hold)
exercises.description: An advanced static hold with body horizontal in front of bar.
instructions: From dead hang, engage lats powerfully
Raise body to horizontal position with arms straight
Maintain perfect straight line from head to toes
Hold static position for time
tips: One of the most difficult static holds
Progress through tuck, advanced tuck, straddle progressions
Can take 1-2 years of dedicated training
common_mistakes: Body piking instead of staying straight

exercises.name: Planche Progression
exercises.description: Progressive steps toward holding a full planche.
instructions: Progress through: frog stand, tuck planche, advanced tuck, straddle planche
For full planche: achieve horizontal body position with only hands touching ground
Arms straight, shoulders protracted, body parallel to floor
Requires years of specific strength training
tips: One of the ultimate calisthenics skills
Requires exceptional shoulder and core strength
Lean progressions and pseudo planche push-ups help build strength

exercises.name: Power Clean
exercises.description: An explosive Olympic lift pulling the barbell from floor to shoulders in one motion, catching in partial squat.
instructions: Start with barbell over mid-foot, shins vertical, shoulders over bar with clean grip
First pull: Push through legs keeping back angle constant until bar reaches knees
Second pull: Explosively extend hips, knees, ankles (triple extension) while shrugging bar upward
Catch bar on shoulders in quarter squat, elbows high, stand to full extension
tips: Bar should brush thighs at hip crease during second pull
Focus on speed under bar, not height of pull
Front rack position requires wrist and shoulder mobility
common_mistakes: Catching on toes instead of full foot

exercises.name: Squat Clean
exercises.description: Full Olympic clean catching the bar in a full front squat position.
instructions: Perform same setup and pull as power clean
After triple extension, pull yourself under bar aggressively
Catch bar in full depth front squat with elbows high
Stand up from bottom of squat to complete lift
tips: Allows lifting heavier loads than power clean
Requires excellent ankle and hip mobility
Gateway to clean and jerk
common_mistakes: Not getting deep enough in catch
Elbows dropping causing bar to roll off shoulders

exercises.name: Hang Clean
exercises.description: Clean variation starting with bar at mid-thigh or knee height rather than floor.
instructions: Start standing with bar at mid-thigh, slight knee bend, shoulders over bar
Dip by bending knees slightly while maintaining back angle
Explosively extend hips and knees while shrugging bar upward
Pull under bar and catch in front rack position
tips: Easier to learn than full clean from floor
Emphasizes hip extension and speed under bar
Great for high-rep MetCons

exercises.name: Power Snatch
exercises.description: Explosive Olympic lift moving bar from floor to overhead in one motion, catching in partial squat.
instructions: Start with wide snatch grip (bar in hip crease when standing), shoulders over bar
First pull maintaining back angle until bar reaches knees
Explosive triple extension with aggressive shoulder shrug
Pull under bar catching overhead with arms locked in partial squat
tips: Requires significant mobility and coordination
Wider grip means longer bar path than clean
Queen of Olympic lifts for total body power
common_mistakes: Grip too narrow reducing power transfer
Pressing bar overhead instead of pulling under

exercises.name: Squat Snatch
exercises.description: Full Olympic snatch catching bar overhead in full depth squat.
instructions: Perform same setup and pull as power snatch with wide grip
After triple extension, aggressively pull yourself under bar
Catch in full overhead squat with arms locked, bar overhead
Stand up from bottom maintaining overhead position
tips: Most technical of all barbell lifts
Requires exceptional mobility in ankles, hips, and shoulders
Can take years to master
common_mistakes: Not achieving full depth in catch
Insufficient shoulder mobility causing forward lean

exercises.name: Hang Snatch
exercises.description: Snatch variation starting from mid-thigh or knee rather than floor.
instructions: Start standing with wide snatch grip, bar at mid-thigh
Slight dip maintaining shoulder-over-bar position
Explosive hip and knee extension with shrug
Pull under bar catching overhead with locked arms
tips: Reduces complexity by removing first pull from floor
Better for high-rep conditioning work
Emphasizes hip power and speed

exercises.name: Clean and Jerk
exercises.description: The king of barbell lifts - clean to shoulders then jerk overhead for maximum weight capacity.
instructions: Perform squat clean bringing bar to shoulders in front rack
Stand fully then reset feet to shoulder-width for jerk
Dip by bending knees 4-6 inches keeping torso vertical
Drive explosively through legs then split or press jerk overhead to lockout
tips: Most efficient method for maximal overhead weight
Combination of two complex movements
Competition standard: Clean + split jerk
common_mistakes: Not standing fully after clean before jerk
Dipping forward in jerk instead of straight down

exercises.name: Push Press
exercises.description: Overhead press using leg drive to assist moving heavier loads.
instructions: Start with barbell in front rack position, hands just outside shoulders
Dip by bending knees 4-6 inches keeping torso vertical and elbows high
Drive explosively through legs transferring power to bar
Press bar overhead to full lockout with arms and legs fully extended
tips: Gateway movement to push jerk and split jerk
Allows 30% more weight than strict press
Keep bar path vertical - straight up and down
common_mistakes: Dipping forward instead of straight down
Not achieving full hip extension in drive

exercises.name: Push Jerk
exercises.description: Dynamic overhead movement using leg drive and receiving bar with bent knees.
instructions: Start with bar in front rack, perform dip as in push press
Explosive drive through legs
Instead of pressing bar up, press yourself under the bar
Receive bar overhead with slight knee bend, then stand to full extension
tips: Allows heavier loads than push press
Faster for MetCons than split jerk
Foot position stays same throughout
common_mistakes: Pressing bar instead of pressing under

exercises.name: Split Jerk
exercises.description: The most stable overhead receiving position using a split stance.
instructions: From front rack, perform dip and drive as in push jerk
Split legs front and back while pressing under bar
Receive bar overhead in split stance: front shin vertical, back knee slightly bent
Step front foot back halfway, then back foot forward to finish standing
tips: Most stable position for maximal loads
Requires practice to find optimal split distance
Olympic standard for clean and jerk
common_mistakes: Split too narrow or too wide
Not achieving full lockout before recovery

exercises.name: Overhead Squat
exercises.description: Full depth squat with barbell held in overhead locked position throughout.
instructions: Start with barbell overhead in snatch grip, arms fully locked
Initiate squat by pushing hips back and bending knees
Descend to full depth keeping arms locked and bar over mid-foot
Drive through heels to stand maintaining overhead position
tips: Tests and builds mobility in ankles, hips, thoracic spine, shoulders
Essential for snatch receiving position
Bar should be slightly behind head when viewed from side

exercises.name: Snatch Balance
exercises.description: Dynamic movement building speed and confidence in overhead squat receiving position.
instructions: Start with bar on back in snatch grip
Small dip then drive bar upward off shoulders
Press yourself under bar into full overhead squat
Receive bar overhead with locked arms in bottom of squat, stand up
tips: Builds confidence and speed for snatch receiving
Bar should barely travel upward - you travel down
Fast feet and aggressive drop crucial
common_mistakes: Pressing bar too high instead of pressing under

exercises.name: Back Squat
exercises.description: The fundamental leg strengthening movement with bar on back of shoulders.
instructions: Set bar on upper back/traps, hands outside shoulders, feet shoulder-width
Unrack bar and step back, establish stance
Initiate squat by pushing hips back, then bending knees
Descend below parallel (hip crease below knee), drive through heels to stand
tips: King of leg exercises for strength building
Chest up and core braced throughout
Full range of motion critical for CrossFit
common_mistakes: Not achieving full depth below parallel

exercises.name: Front Squat
exercises.description: Squat with barbell in front rack position emphasizing core and upper back.
instructions: Set bar in front rack on shoulders, elbows high, hands just outside shoulders
Feet shoulder-width, toes slightly out
Squat down keeping torso as vertical as possible, elbows high
Descend below parallel, drive through heels maintaining upright torso
tips: More quad and core emphasis than back squat
Essential for clean receiving position
Requires wrist and shoulder mobility for proper rack
common_mistakes: Elbows dropping causing bar to roll forward

exercises.name: Deadlift
exercises.description: The fundamental hip hinge movement lifting barbell from floor to standing.
instructions: Approach bar with mid-foot under bar, feet hip-width apart
Grip bar just outside legs, drop hips, chest up, shoulders over bar
Engage lats pulling slack out of bar, take deep breath and brace core
Drive through floor extending hips and knees simultaneously to stand fully
tips: Foundation of all pulling movements
Bar should travel in straight vertical line
Most weight can be lifted with this movement

exercises.name: Bench Press
exercises.description: Fundamental horizontal pressing movement lying on bench.
instructions: Lie on bench with eyes under bar, feet flat on floor
Grip bar slightly wider than shoulder-width, unrack with straight arms
Lower bar to chest with controlled descent
Press bar back up to full lockout
tips: Retract shoulder blades and maintain throughout
Bar should touch chest at nipple line
Less emphasized in CrossFit than overhead pressing
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Kettlebell Swing (Russian)
exercises.description: Hip-driven kettlebell swing to chest height emphasizing posterior chain power.
instructions: Stand with feet shoulder-width, kettlebell on ground between feet
Hinge at hips, grip kettlebell with both hands
Hike bell back between legs, then explosively extend hips driving bell forward
Bell swings to chest height at peak of hip extension, arms remain straight throughout
tips: This is a HIP movement, not a squat or arm raise
Powerful hip snap generates all momentum
Better for heavy loading and strength than American swing
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms instead of hip drive

exercises.name: Kettlebell Swing (American)
exercises.description: Hip-driven swing taking kettlebell fully overhead requiring shoulder mobility.
instructions: Start same as Russian swing with hip hinge and kettlebell grip
Explosive hip extension driving bell forward and upward
Continue momentum bringing bell fully overhead to lockout
Control descent back through arc to hip hinge position
tips: Standard in CrossFit workouts for increased range of motion
Requires good shoulder mobility and overhead control
More work per rep but lighter loading than Russian
common_mistakes: Pressing bell overhead with arms instead of hip drive
Insufficient shoulder mobility causing arched back
Dropping bell too quickly on descent

exercises.name: Kettlebell Snatch
exercises.description: Explosive single-arm movement taking kettlebell from ground to overhead in one motion.
instructions: Start with kettlebell between feet, hinge and grip with one hand
Explosively extend hips driving bell upward
As bell rises, punch hand through rotating bell around forearm
Catch bell overhead with locked arm, then lower with control and switch arms
