tips: Rotation around forearm prevents banging wrist
Builds unilateral power and shoulder stability
Can be done in high-rep conditioning sets
common_mistakes: Curling bell instead of punching through
Bell flipping over and banging forearm

exercises.name: Kettlebell Clean
exercises.description: Explosive movement bringing kettlebell from ground to rack position at shoulder.
instructions: Start with kettlebell between feet, hinge and grip with one hand
Drive hips forward explosively as in swing
As bell rises, pull elbow back and rotate hand inserting it into handle
Receive bell in rack position at shoulder, bell resting on forearm
tips: Bell should land softly in rack position, not bang
Gateway to kettlebell clean and jerk or thruster
Keep elbow tight to ribs in rack position
common_mistakes: Banging bell onto forearm in rack

exercises.name: Turkish Get-up
exercises.description: Complex full-body movement transitioning from lying to standing with kettlebell overhead.
instructions: Lie on back, press kettlebell overhead with right arm, bend right knee
Roll to left elbow then post to left hand, maintaining overhead lockout
Bridge hips up, sweep left leg through to half-kneeling position
Stand up keeping bell overhead, reverse entire sequence to return to lying
tips: Keep eyes on kettlebell throughout entire movement
Builds shoulder stability and total body control
Master with no weight before loading

exercises.name: Goblet Squat
exercises.description: Front-loaded squat holding kettlebell at chest promoting upright torso.
instructions: Hold kettlebell by horns at chest height, elbows tucked
Feet shoulder-width apart, toes slightly out
Squat down keeping torso vertical and elbows inside knees
Descend below parallel, drive through heels to stand
tips: Excellent for teaching squat mechanics
Front loading encourages upright torso
Great warm-up or scaled alternative to barbell squats

exercises.name: Kettlebell Thruster
exercises.description: Combination of goblet squat and overhead press in one fluid movement.
instructions: Hold kettlebell in goblet position at chest
Squat to full depth maintaining upright torso
Drive powerfully out of squat using leg drive to press bell overhead
Lower bell to chest and immediately descend into next rep
tips: One continuous movement with no pause between squat and press
Leg drive does most of work pressing bell overhead
Brutal for conditioning workouts
common_mistakes: Pausing at top of squat before press
Not using leg drive for press

exercises.name: Kipping Pull-up
exercises.description: Dynamic pull-up using hip drive and kip swing to generate momentum.
instructions: Hang from bar, initiate kip by swinging from hollow to arch position
From arch, drive hips forward and push down on bar
This hip pop generates upward momentum to pull chin over bar
Push away from bar descending back to arch, return to hollow
tips: Requires strict pull-up strength foundation first
Much more efficient for high-rep workouts than strict
Kip rhythm is key - timing of hip drive critical
common_mistakes: Not achieving full range: chin over bar, full extension at bottom

exercises.name: Butterfly Pull-up
exercises.description: The fastest pull-up variation using circular shoulder-initiated movement.
instructions: From hang, initiate shoulder-driven kip creating circular momentum
Pull to bar while pushing legs backward
Immediately push away from bar as chin clears
Swing legs forward maintaining continuous circular motion
tips: Fastest pull-up method for competition
Requires 15-20 kipping pull-ups before attempting
Shoulder-intensive - requires proper strength and mobility

exercises.name: Chest-to-Bar Pull-up
exercises.description: Pull-up requiring chest to touch bar at top for greater range of motion.
instructions: Using kipping technique, generate hip drive
Pull aggressively bringing chest to bar (not just chin over)
Contact point typically at collarbone or upper chest
Push away and descend with control maintaining rhythm
tips: Requires more pulling strength than regular kipping pull-up
Essential prerequisite for bar muscle-ups
Can be done strict or kipping
common_mistakes: Only getting chin over bar, not chest contact
Excessive arch causing only lower chest to touch

exercises.name: Bar Muscle-up
exercises.description: Dynamic movement transitioning from pull-up to dip above the bar.
instructions: Generate aggressive kip and pull explosively to bar
At peak of pull, lean forward aggressively bringing hips to bar
Transition by rotating around bar bringing chest up and over
Press out to full support position with arms locked above bar
tips: Requires chest-to-bar pull-up and strong dip strength
Hip-to-bar contact helps with transition
False grip can assist but isn't required
common_mistakes: Not pulling high enough before transition

exercises.name: Ring Muscle-up
exercises.description: Muscle-up performed on gymnastic rings requiring greater control than bar.
instructions: From false grip hang, generate kip and pull explosively
At top of pull, lean back slightly and pull rings to chest
Transition by rotating wrists over and pressing through dip
Finish in full support position with rings at hips, arms locked
tips: False grip (wrist over ring) makes transition easier
Turn rings out at top to stabilize
Often easier to learn than bar muscle-up
common_mistakes: Not getting high enough in pull phase
Chicken-winging one arm at a time

exercises.name: Toes-to-Bar
exercises.description: Hanging ab movement bringing toes to touch pull-up bar.
instructions: Hang from bar with shoulder-width grip
Generate small kip from arch to hollow position
From arch, press down on bar while bringing legs up
Touch toes to bar between hands, lower with control maintaining rhythm
tips: Kipping rhythm allows higher reps than strict
Keep arms relatively straight throughout
Timing of lat press and leg lift is crucial
common_mistakes: Not achieving toe contact with bar

exercises.name: Knees-to-Elbows
exercises.description: Hanging ab movement bringing knees up to touch elbows.
instructions: Hang from bar establishing slight kip
From arch position, press bar down while bringing knees up
Touch knees to elbows at top
Lower with control returning to arch
tips: Scaled version of toes-to-bar
Still requires core strength and coordination
Can be done strict or with kip

exercises.name: Handstand Walk
exercises.description: Walking in handstand position requiring balance, strength, and coordination.
instructions: Kick up into freestanding handstand
Shift weight to one hand while stepping other hand forward
Continuously shift weight and step hands forward
Maintain tight core and stacked shoulders throughout
tips: Master freestanding handstand hold first (30+ seconds)
Look at hands, not forward
Small frequent steps better than large steps
common_mistakes: Looking forward instead of at hands
Taking steps too large causing instability

exercises.name: Wall Balls
exercises.description: Squat to overhead throw using medicine ball against wall target.
instructions: Hold medicine ball at chest, stand facing wall 12 inches away
Squat to full depth with ball at chest
Drive explosively out of squat throwing ball to 10-foot target
Catch ball on descent and immediately drop into next squat
tips: One fluid movement - squat and throw are connected
Standard: 20lb/14lb ball to 10ft/9ft target
Use leg drive, not just arms to throw ball

exercises.name: Box Jumps
exercises.description: Explosive jump onto elevated box emphasizing hip extension and power.
instructions: Stand facing box at arm's distance
Swing arms back while loading hips
Jump explosively driving through full hip extension
Land on box with full foot contact, stand to full hip extension, step down
tips: Standard heights: 24 inches men, 20 inches women
Full hip extension at top is standard
Step-down option safer for high reps
common_mistakes: Not standing fully on box (incomplete rep)
Jumping down instead of stepping (injury risk)

exercises.name: Double Unders
exercises.description: Jump rope variation with two rope passes per jump.
instructions: Hold rope handles with relaxed grip, rope behind heels
Jump slightly higher than single under
Spin rope fast using wrists (not big arm circles)
Rope passes under feet twice before landing
tips: Stay on balls of feet, soft knees
Fast wrists, slow feet - not opposite
Speed rope essential for learning

exercises.name: Rope Climbs
exercises.description: Climbing rope from ground to specified height using legs and arms.
instructions: Jump and grab rope high, wrap rope around one leg and step on it with other foot
Stand up on rope using legs while reaching higher with arms
Rewrap rope with legs and repeat reach-stand sequence
Touch target height (typically 15 feet), descend with control
tips: Legs do most of work - arms just reach and hold
Multiple foot wrap techniques - find what works for you
Descend controlled to protect hands and shoulders
common_mistakes: Sliding down too fast causing rope burn

exercises.name: Assault Bike
exercises.description: Fan bike providing full-body cardiovascular conditioning.
instructions: Sit on bike with feet on pedals, hands on handles
Push and pull handles while pedaling simultaneously
Maintain steady breathing and sustainable pace for longer efforts
For sprints, go all-out effort coordinating arms and legs
tips: Measured in calories or distance
Harder you work, more resistance it provides
Notorious for being brutal in workouts
common_mistakes: Starting too fast on longer intervals

exercises.name: Rowing (Erg)
exercises.description: Full-body cardiovascular exercise on rowing machine.
instructions: Sit on rower with feet strapped in, grab handle with overhand grip
Start with knees bent, arms straight, shoulders forward of hips
Drive with legs first, then lean back, finally pull handle to chest
Reverse order: extend arms, lean forward, bend knees to return
tips: Legs-back-arms on drive, arms-back-legs on recovery
Power comes from legs (60%), not arms
Measured in meters, calories, or time
common_mistakes: Pulling with arms first instead of driving legs
Overreaching at catch causing back rounding

exercises.name: Sled Push/Pull
exercises.description: Pushing or pulling weighted sled for strength and conditioning.
instructions: For push: hands on sled posts, lean forward, drive through legs with powerful strides
For pull: attach rope/strap, lean back and pull hand-over-hand walking backward
Maintain strong core and continuous movement
Complete specified distance
tips: Low sled position = more leg emphasis
Keep head up and core braced
Great for building work capacity without eccentric damage
common_mistakes: Not loading sled appropriately for workout intent
Taking too long between pulls losing intensity

exercises.name: Farmers Carry
exercises.description: Walking while carrying heavy weight in each hand.
instructions: Pick up heavy dumbbell or kettlebell in each hand
Stand tall with shoulders back, core braced
Walk with controlled strides for specified distance or time
Maintain upright posture throughout, don't let shoulders shrug up
tips: Builds tremendous grip strength and core stability
Go heavy - should be challenging to maintain posture
Great finisher for workouts

exercises.name: Sandbag Carry
exercises.description: Carrying heavy sandbag in bear hug position for distance or time.
instructions: Pick up sandbag from ground using deadlift mechanics
Bring to chest/shoulder position in bear hug
Walk for specified distance maintaining upright posture
Set down with control
tips: Sandbag shifts making it unstable - great for core
Can carry in various positions: bear hug, shoulder, overhead
Functional real-world strength builder
common_mistakes: Not bracing core causing excessive lean

exercises.name: Burpees
exercises.description: Full-body conditioning movement: chest to ground, jump, and clap overhead.
instructions: From standing, drop hands to ground and jump or step feet back to plank
Lower chest and thighs to ground completely
Push up to plank, jump or step feet to hands
Jump up and clap hands overhead with full hip extension
tips: CrossFit standard: chest to ground, full hip extension with clap
Find rhythm that's sustainable for high reps
Variations: bar-facing burpees, burpee box jump-overs
common_mistakes: Not achieving full hip extension at top
Going too fast too early causing burnout

exercises.name: Easy/Recovery Run
exercises.description: Low-intensity run for active recovery and building aerobic base without stress.
instructions: Run at conversational pace where you can easily talk in full sentences
Keep heart rate in Zone 1-2 (60-70% max HR)
Focus on comfortable breathing rhythm, not pace or distance
Duration typically 20-60 minutes depending on fitness level
tips: Should feel 'too easy' - this is intentional for recovery
Day after hard workout or race is perfect timing
Builds aerobic base without adding fatigue
common_mistakes: Running too fast defeating recovery purpose
Skipping easy runs thinking they don't matter
Comparing pace to others - easy is individual

exercises.name: Tempo Run
exercises.description: Sustained run at comfortably hard pace just below lactate threshold to build endurance.
instructions: Warm up 10-15 minutes with easy running
Run 20-30 minutes at 'comfortably hard' pace (can speak in short phrases only)
Pace should be slightly slower than 10K race pace or ~85% max HR
Cool down 10 minutes easy to complete workout
tips: Improves lactate threshold allowing faster sustained pace
Mental toughness builder - practice holding discomfort
Should finish feeling worked but not destroyed
common_mistakes: Starting tempo portion too fast and fading
Running at full race pace instead of controlled tempo

exercises.name: Interval Training (Track)
exercises.description: Short intense efforts with recovery periods to build speed and VO2 max.
instructions: Warm up thoroughly with 1-2 miles easy running plus drills
Example: 12 x 400m at 5K pace with 400m easy jog recovery between
Maintain consistent pace for each interval - don't start too fast
Cool down 10-15 minutes easy running
tips: Recovery is crucial - discipline during jog allows strong next rep
Can structure on time or distance based on goal
Builds speed endurance and running economy
common_mistakes: Running first interval too fast causing fade

exercises.name: Fartlek Run
exercises.description: Swedish 'speed play' - unstructured run alternating between fast and slow segments.
instructions: Begin with 10-minute easy warm-up
Alternate between fast surges (1-3 minutes) and easy recovery jogs
Base speed changes on feel, terrain, or landmarks - no set structure
Total duration 30-60 minutes including easy portions
tips: More flexible and fun than structured intervals
Great for practicing finishing kick in races
Can adapt intensity based on how you feel that day
common_mistakes: Making surges too long or too hard
Losing the 'playful' aspect and making it too structured

exercises.name: Long Run
exercises.description: Extended distance run building aerobic endurance and mental toughness.
instructions: Run at easy conversational pace for extended duration
Distance typically 90-180 minutes or 20-30% of weekly mileage
Stay aerobic - should be able to hold conversation throughout
Fuel and hydrate appropriately for runs over 90 minutes
tips: Cornerstone of marathon and half-marathon training
Builds aerobic engine and fat-burning efficiency
Don't worry about pace - time on feet matters most
common_mistakes: Running too fast depleting glycogen stores
Neglecting fueling on runs over 90 minutes

exercises.name: Hill Repeats
exercises.description: Repeated uphill sprints building power, strength, and running economy.
instructions: Warm up 10-15 minutes easy running on flat terrain
Run uphill at 90% effort for 60-90 seconds maintaining form
Jog down slowly for recovery (not walking) keeping heart rate elevated
Repeat 6-10 times, cool down 10 minutes easy
tips: Intervals in disguise - builds strength with less joint impact
Improves running form through exaggerated mechanics
Recovery jog down is key - keeps workout aerobic
common_mistakes: Going all-out instead of controlled 90% effort
Walking down hill instead of jogging
Letting form break down on later reps

exercises.name: Sprint Intervals
exercises.description: Very short maximum effort sprints developing top-end speed and power.
instructions: Extensive warm-up: 15-20 minutes easy running, dynamic drills, 3-4 strides
Sprint 100-200m at 95-98% max effort with excellent form
Walk or jog 2-3 minutes for full recovery between reps
Perform 6-10 reps maintaining quality, cool down thoroughly
tips: Quality over quantity - stop if form deteriorates
Full recovery between reps is essential
Develops neuromuscular system and fast-twitch fibers
common_mistakes: Inadequate warm-up leading to injury risk
Doing too many reps sacrificing quality

exercises.name: Progression Run
exercises.description: Run starting easy and progressively getting faster, finishing at tempo or faster pace.
instructions: Start first portion (40-50%) at easy conversational pace
Middle portion (30-40%) gradually increase to moderate effort
Final portion (10-20%) push to tempo pace or slightly faster
Example: 6 miles total - 3 miles easy, 2 miles moderate, 1 mile tempo
tips: Teaches pacing discipline and finishing strong
Less taxing than tempo run but builds similar fitness
Great for race simulation and negative split practice
common_mistakes: Starting progression too early in run
Not making final portion hard enough
Increasing pace too dramatically causing burnout

exercises.name: A-Skips
exercises.description: Dynamic running drill emphasizing proper knee drive, posture, and ground contact.
instructions: Skip forward with exaggerated knee lift to hip height
Support leg performs quick skip (two contacts per cycle)
Opposite arm and leg move together (left knee up, right arm forward)
Land on ball of foot directly under center of mass, maintain upright posture
tips: Focus on rhythm and timing - should sound rhythmic
Knee goes straight up and straight down, no forward kick
Essential warm-up drill for speed workouts
common_mistakes: Same arm and leg moving together
Leaning forward or backward instead of staying tall

exercises.name: B-Skips
exercises.description: Advanced running drill adding leg extension to A-skip for hamstring engagement and pawing action.
instructions: Perform A-skip bringing knee to hip height
Extend leg forward kicking foot out and up
Pull foot down and back in pawing motion landing under hips
Drive ground contact backward while skipping on support leg
tips: Emphasizes hamstring activation and proper ground contact
Pawing motion mimics proper running mechanics
More complex than A-skip, takes practice to master
common_mistakes: Not extending leg fully before pawing down
Landing foot in front of body instead of under hips

exercises.name: High Knees
exercises.description: Running drill emphasizing quick knee drive and rapid foot turnover.
instructions: Run in place or move forward with exaggerated knee lift
Drive knees up to hip height rapidly
Land on balls of feet with quick ground contact
Pump arms vigorously in running motion, maintain upright posture
tips: Focus on speed and frequency of knee drive
Great for activating hip flexors pre-run
Can be done in place or moving forward
common_mistakes: Leaning backward instead of staying upright
Slow cadence instead of rapid fire
Not lifting knees to hip height

exercises.name: Butt Kicks
exercises.description: Running drill emphasizing quick heel recovery toward glutes.
instructions: Run in place or move forward bringing heels up toward glutes
Emphasize quick heel snap to butt with minimal forward movement
Maintain upright posture with engaged core
Perform for 20-30 meters or 20-30 seconds
tips: Activates hamstrings and teaches quick heel recovery
Should feel bounce in glutes
Common pre-run activation drill
common_mistakes: Kicking heels out to side instead of straight back
Moving forward too much instead of emphasizing heel snap

exercises.name: Carioca (Grapevine)
exercises.description: Lateral running drill improving hip mobility, coordination, and agility.
instructions: Move laterally crossing one leg in front then behind the other
Keep hips and shoulders facing forward while moving sideways
Maintain athletic stance with slight knee bend
Perform 20-30 meters each direction
tips: Opens up hips and improves hip rotation
Coordination drill beneficial for injury prevention
Start slowly then increase speed as comfortable
common_mistakes: Rotating entire body instead of keeping shoulders square

exercises.name: Bounding
exercises.description: Explosive plyometric drill emphasizing power, stride length, and air time.
instructions: Run forward with exaggerated stride length and hang time
Drive powerfully off each foot maximizing horizontal distance
Drive knee up and forward, extend fully through push-off leg
Focus on covering maximum ground per bound for 30-50 meters
tips: Builds explosive power and stride length
Should feel like slow-motion running with emphasis on power
Advanced drill - requires strength foundation
common_mistakes: Rushing cadence instead of emphasizing power per stride
Not achieving full extension on push-off
Leaning too far forward losing upright posture

exercises.name: Straight Leg Runs
exercises.description: Running drill with minimal knee bend emphasizing hamstring and glute engagement.
instructions: Run forward keeping legs relatively straight with minimal knee bend
Emphasize dorsiflexed foot (toes up) throughout
Drive legs from hip with glutes, land on ball of foot
Perform for 20-30 meters focusing on hamstring and glute activation
tips: Teaches posterior chain engagement in running
Should feel significant hamstring and glute work
Also called 'straight leg bounds' or 'frankensteins'
common_mistakes: Not dorsiflexing foot (toes should point up)
Leaning backward instead of maintaining posture

exercises.name: Fast Feet
exercises.description: Rapid-fire drill emphasizing quick ground contact and foot turnover.
instructions: Run in place with extremely quick, short steps
Minimize ground contact time - stay on balls of feet
Keep knee lift minimal, focus on rapid cadence
Perform for 10-20 seconds at maximum frequency
tips: Develops quick foot turnover and reactive ground contact
Should sound like rapid patter on ground
Great neuromuscular activation drill
common_mistakes: Lifting knees too high slowing cadence
Landing on heels instead of balls of feet

exercises.name: Falling Starts
exercises.description: Acceleration drill teaching proper forward lean and powerful drive phase.
instructions: Stand tall with feet together, body straight like a plank
Lean forward from ankles (not hips) until you start to fall
At last moment, drive one leg forward to catch yourself
Accelerate for 10-20 meters maintaining forward lean
tips: Teaches proper acceleration mechanics with forward lean
Helps develop powerful first steps
Great for sprinters and speed development
common_mistakes: Bending at hips instead of leaning from ankles
Standing up too soon losing forward lean
Not driving powerfully off back leg

exercises.name: Strides
exercises.description: Controlled accelerations building to near-max speed with focus on smooth form.
instructions: Accelerate gradually over 50-70 meters building to 85-90% max speed
Hold top speed for 10-15 seconds maintaining smooth relaxed form
Decelerate smoothly, walk or jog to full recovery (1-2 minutes)
Perform 4-8 repetitions focusing on form not exhaustion
tips: Not sprints - should be controlled and smooth
Excellent for neuromuscular activation and speed work introduction
Can add to easy runs or pre-race warm-ups
common_mistakes: Running too hard turning them into sprints
Poor form due to excessive effort

exercises.name: Leg Swings (Front/Back)
exercises.description: Dynamic warm-up mobilizing hip flexors and hamstrings through sagittal plane.
instructions: Stand on one leg using wall for light support
Swing opposite leg forward and backward in controlled motion
Gradually increase range of motion over 15-20 swings
Keep torso upright and stable, repeat other leg
tips: Start with small swings and progressively increase
Essential pre-run dynamic stretch
Warms up hips through full range of motion
common_mistakes: Rotating torso instead of keeping stable
Using momentum instead of controlled movement

exercises.name: Leg Swings (Side/Side)
exercises.description: Dynamic warm-up mobilizing hip adductors and abductors through frontal plane.
instructions: Stand facing wall with both hands on wall for support
Swing one leg side to side across front of body
Gradually increase range from small to large swings
Perform 15-20 swings each leg keeping hips square forward
tips: Opens up hip joint laterally
Great for runners with tight hips or IT band issues
Keep supporting leg stable
common_mistakes: Rotating hips instead of keeping square
Not achieving full range of motion

exercises.name: Walking Lunges
exercises.description: Dynamic warm-up activating glutes, quads, and hip flexors while improving mobility.
instructions: Step forward into deep lunge with front knee at 90 degrees
Back knee nearly touches ground, front shin vertical
Drive through front heel to step forward into next lunge
Perform 10-15 lunges per leg, can add overhead reach or twist
tips: Essential dynamic warm-up for runners
Activates glutes and stretches hip flexors simultaneously
Add variations like overhead reach or twist for more benefit
common_mistakes: Not achieving full depth in lunge

exercises.name: Inch Worms
exercises.description: Full-body dynamic stretch emphasizing hamstring flexibility and core activation.
instructions: From standing, bend at hips keeping legs straight and walk hands out to plank
Perform optional push-up in plank position
Walk feet toward hands keeping legs as straight as possible
Stand up and repeat for 5-8 repetitions
tips: Stretches hamstrings and calves dynamically
Activates core and shoulders
Great full-body warm-up movement
common_mistakes: Bending knees too much losing hamstring stretch
Letting hips sag in plank position

exercises.name: World's Greatest Stretch
exercises.description: Comprehensive dynamic stretch combining lunge, rotation, and hip opening.
instructions: Step into deep lunge position with hands on ground inside front foot
Drop back knee to ground, rotate torso and reach front-side arm toward ceiling
Return hand to ground, straighten front leg for hamstring stretch
Return to lunge, step forward and repeat other side for 5-8 reps each
tips: Lives up to name - hits hips, hamstrings, and thoracic rotation
Perfect pre-run dynamic warm-up
Move slowly through each position
common_mistakes: Not achieving full rotation in twist

exercises.name: Hip Circles
exercises.description: Dynamic mobility drill rotating hip joint through full range of motion.
instructions: Stand on one leg, lift other knee to hip height
Rotate lifted leg in large circles from the hip joint
Perform 8-10 circles forward, then 8-10 circles backward
Switch legs and repeat
tips: Mobilizes hip joint in all directions
Helps prevent IT band and hip issues
Keep supporting leg stable with engaged core
common_mistakes: Circling from knee instead of hip
Wobbling on support leg showing weak stability

exercises.name: Ankle Circles
exercises.description: Mobility drill warming up ankle joint and improving range of motion.
instructions: Stand on one leg or sit, lift other foot off ground
Rotate ankle making large circles with toes
Perform 10 circles clockwise, then 10 counterclockwise
Switch feet and repeat
tips: Important for runners to maintain ankle mobility
Helps prevent ankle injuries and Achilles issues
Can also spell alphabet with toes
common_mistakes: Making small circles not using full range
Moving entire leg instead of just ankle

exercises.name: Incline Walking
exercises.description: Treadmill warm-up or recovery building aerobic base without impact stress.
instructions: Set treadmill to 3-5% incline at moderate walking pace (3-4 mph)
Walk with good posture, driving through heels
Maintain steady breathing for 15-30 minutes
Can progress to steeper inclines or faster pace
tips: Builds leg strength without running impact
Great for recovery days or injury prevention
Activates glutes more than flat walking
common_mistakes: Going too fast turning it into running

exercises.name: Treadmill Intervals
exercises.description: Structured high-intensity intervals on treadmill with controlled pace and recovery.
instructions: Warm up 10 minutes at easy pace on flat treadmill
Example: 8 x 2 minutes at 5K pace with 1 minute easy jog recovery
Adjust speed precisely for work and recovery intervals
Cool down 10 minutes easy to complete workout
tips: Treadmill provides perfect pace control for intervals
Can precisely replicate paces and recoveries
No external factors affecting consistency
common_mistakes: Not warming up sufficiently before intervals
Setting pace too fast for prescribed effort

exercises.name: Treadmill Sprints
exercises.description: Short maximal effort sprints on treadmill developing speed and power.
instructions: Extensive warm-up then set treadmill to high speed (9-11 mph for most)
Straddle treadmill, start belt, jump on for 20-30 second sprint
Jump off to sides, recover 90 seconds to 2 minutes
Perform 6-10 reps maintaining form and speed
tips: Requires practice to safely mount/dismount moving treadmill
Builds pure speed and power
Full recovery essential between reps
common_mistakes: Not being comfortable with treadmill safety

exercises.name: Incline Sprints
exercises.description: Maximum effort sprints on inclined treadmill building power with reduced impact.
instructions: Set treadmill to 7-10% incline after thorough warm-up
Sprint at near-maximum effort for 20-30 seconds
Step off or reduce to walk for 2-3 minute recovery
Perform 6-10 reps, maintaining power output throughout
tips: Safer on joints than flat sprints due to incline
Exceptional for building leg power and strength
Mimics hill sprint benefits in controlled environment

exercises.name: 100m Sprints
exercises.description: Classic short sprint distance developing pure speed and acceleration.
instructions: After extensive warm-up and drills, sprint 100m at 95-100% effort
Focus on explosive start, powerful acceleration, maintaining form
Walk or jog 3-4 minutes for full recovery
Perform 6-10 repetitions maintaining speed and form
tips: Pure speed development distance
Quality over quantity - stop if speed drops significantly
Perfect for developing fast-twitch muscle fibers
common_mistakes: Inadequate warm-up leading to injury risk
Not sprinting at true max effort

exercises.name: 200m Repeats
exercises.description: Mid-distance sprint repeats building speed endurance and lactate tolerance.
instructions: After warm-up, run 200m at 90-95% max effort
Target pace slightly slower than 100m sprint pace
Jog or walk 200m (2-3 minutes) for recovery
Perform 8-12 repetitions maintaining consistent times
tips: Bridges gap between pure sprints and longer intervals
Teaches speed endurance and lactate tolerance
Common middle-distance training staple
common_mistakes: Starting too fast and fading badly
Recovery too short for quality reps

exercises.name: 400m Repeats
exercises.description: Quarter-mile repeats building VO2 max, speed endurance, and mental toughness.
instructions: After warm-up, run 400m at mile race pace or 85-90% max effort
Maintain even pacing - don't go out too hard first 200m
Recover with 400m jog or 2-3 minute rest
Perform 6-12 repetitions depending on fitness and goal
tips: Classic VO2 max interval distance
First 200m should feel controlled, second 200m pushes threshold
Highly effective but very demanding workout
common_mistakes: Not maintaining form as fatigue sets in

exercises.name: Flying 30s
exercises.description: Acceleration into maximum velocity sprint emphasizing top-end speed development.
instructions: After warm-up, accelerate for 30-40m building to near-max speed
At full speed, sprint maximally for 30 meters ('flying' section)
Decelerate gradually over final 20-30 meters
Walk back for full recovery (3-4 minutes), repeat 4-6 times
tips: Develops true maximum velocity running mechanics
Acceleration phase gets you to top speed for flying portion
Advanced drill requiring excellent sprint mechanics
common_mistakes: Not reaching true max velocity before flying section
Poor deceleration technique causing injury risk
